meaning: 吧 has two main uses: (1) As a modal particle pronounced “ba”, placed at the end of a sentence to soften tone, make a suggestion, or show uncertainty, similar to “…right?”, “…OK?”, or “I guess…”. (2) As “bā”, it can mean a bar (as in bar, café, or online forum), or be part of onomatopoeia like a smack or bang.
components: 吧 is ⿰口巴: 口 (mouth) suggests speaking or sounds; 巴 (to cling; also used in many characters) hints at attaching or tagging something on. Put together, a ‘mouth’ plus ‘巴’ gives a sound or tone that ‘clings’ to the end of what you say—an ending particle or a sound like “bang/smack”.

examples.zh: 我们走吧。
examples.pinyin: Wǒmen zǒu ba.
examples.en: Let’s go, shall we?

examples.zh: 这应该没问题吧？
examples.pinyin: Zhè yīnggāi méi wèntí ba?
examples.en: This shouldn’t be a problem, right?

examples.zh: 下班以后去那个酒吧喝一杯吧。
examples.pinyin: Xiàbān yǐhòu qù nàge jiǔbā hē yì bēi ba.
examples.en: After work, let’s go to that bar and have a drink, OK?

memoryStory: Imagine a huge talking MOUTH (口) stuck to the door of a neon BAR (巴). Every time someone speaks, the mouth can’t resist adding a soft “ba?” at the end: “Drink?” becomes “Drink ba?”, “Go?” becomes “Go ba?”. The clingy 巴 bar-mouth always sticks a gentle question on your sentences.
imagePrompt: A futuristic neon bar counter shaped like a big open mouth, glowing in a cyberpunk city. Holographic speech bubbles float out of the mouth, gently curving like question marks. Network cables and light-lines connect the bar to surrounding buildings, suggesting soft, shared suggestions across a digital city.
rawDictEntry: 吧 吧 [bā] /bar (loanword) (serving drinks, or providing Internet access etc)/to puff (on a pipe etc)/(onom.) bang/abbr. for 貼吧|贴吧[tiē bā]/

meaning: 白 (bái) primarily means “white; pure; bright; blank; plain; clear.” It can also mean “in vain; for nothing; free of charge; gratuitous,” and as a verb “to explain; to state clearly.” As a noun it can refer to spoken vernacular or spoken lines in opera, and it is also a common Chinese surname (Bái).
components: 白 is itself a single-component character and also a radical. The top short stroke suggests a shining point of light, and the larger shape below suggests a surface or object being lit up. Together they evoke something bright, pure, and clearly visible — the idea of whiteness and clarity.

examples.zh: 今天的天空很蓝，云却很白。
examples.pinyin: Jīntiān de tiānkōng hěn lán, yún què hěn bái.
examples.en: The sky is very blue today, but the clouds are really white.

examples.zh: 这张纸是空白的，你可以随便画。
examples.pinyin: Zhè zhāng zhǐ shì kòngbái de, nǐ kěyǐ suíbiàn huà.
examples.en: This sheet of paper is blank; you can draw whatever you like.

examples.zh: 我白等了一个小时，他没来。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ bái děng le yī ge xiǎoshí, tā méi lái.
examples.en: I waited an hour for nothing; he didn’t come.

memoryStory: Imagine a superstar named Bái standing on a stage made of pure white light. One tiny spotlight (the top stroke) shines on a huge glowing white square under his feet. He shouts, “All for free, totally pure!” and the crowd remembers: bái = white, pure, for nothing.
imagePrompt: A glowing white square platform floating in a dark futuristic city, a single bright beam of light shining down on it from above, everything around in shadow. Neon network lines radiate from the white platform like circuits, emphasizing its pure, bright whiteness.

meaning: 百 (bǎi) means “hundred.” It can also extend to “hundreds,” “numerous,” or “all kinds of.” As a proper noun with capital B (Bǎi), it is a Chinese surname.
components: 百 is written as ⿱一白: the top stroke 一 suggests a cap or top limit; below is 白 (bái), which originally means “white” or “bright.” You can imagine a bright, shining stack capped at the top to mean a complete set of one hundred.

examples.zh: 这里大概有一百个人。
examples.pinyin: Zhèlǐ dàgài yǒu yì bǎi gè rén.

examples.zh: 他有百种不同的兴趣。
examples.pinyin: Tā yǒu bǎi zhǒng bùtóng de xìngqù.

examples.zh: 失败是成功之母，经历百次也别放弃。
examples.pinyin: Shībài shì chénggōng zhī mǔ, jīnglì bǎi cì yě bié fàngqì.
examples.en: Failure is the mother of success; even after a hundred tries, don’t give up.

meaning: 帮助 means to help, assist, or give aid to someone. It can refer both to the action of helping (to help, to assist) and to the assistance itself (help, aid, support).
components: 帮: ⿱邦巾 — ‘邦’ (bāng, state/country) over ‘巾’ (jīn, cloth/towel). Imagine an official from a state using a cloth or towel to help someone clean up a mess. 助: ⿰且力 — ‘且’ (qiě, originally a pictograph that can suggest a container or something in front) plus ‘力’ (lì, strength, power). Picture someone adding their strength in front of you to give you a boost. Together, 帮助 combines the idea of a state/official offering practical help (布巾) and someone adding their strength (力) right beside you: to help, to assist.

examples.zh: 谢谢你的帮助，我才能按时完成作业。
examples.pinyin: Xièxie nǐ de bāngzhù, wǒ cái néng ànshí wánchéng zuòyè.
examples.en: Thanks to your help, I was able to finish my homework on time.

examples.en: If you need help, tell me anytime.

examples.zh: 这个应用可以帮助你学习中文。

examples.en: This app can help you learn Chinese.

meaning: Newspaper; printed sheets that report news, events, and other information, usually published daily or weekly. Also refers to the physical newsprint paper itself. Commonly counted with 份, 期, or 张.
components: 报: 扌 (hand) + 𠬝 (phonetic component, related to “tell/announce”) → a hand delivering or reporting something. 纸: 纟 (silk, thread → things made from fibers) + 氏 (phonetic component) → fiber-based material → paper. Together, 报纸 is literally “report-paper,” i.e., newspaper.

examples.zh: 他每天早上一边喝咖啡一边看报纸。
examples.pinyin: Tā měi tiān zǎo shang yībiān hē kāfēi yībiān kàn bàozhǐ.
examples.en: Every morning he drinks coffee while reading the newspaper.

examples.zh: 今天的报纸上有一条很重要的新闻。
examples.pinyin: Jīntiān de bàozhǐ shàng yǒu yī tiáo hěn zhòngyào de xīnwén.
examples.en: There is a very important piece of news in today’s newspaper.

examples.zh: 现在很多人不看纸质报纸，只看手机上的新闻。
examples.pinyin: Xiànzài hěn duō rén bù kàn zhǐzhì bàozhǐ, zhǐ kàn shǒujī shàng de xīnwén.
examples.en: Nowadays many people don’t read paper newspapers, they only read news on their phones.

memoryStory: A reporter with a huge HAND (扌) runs through the city shouting news so loudly (报, to report) that silk THREADS (纟) in the air weave themselves into giant sheets of PAPER (纸). He slaps a fresh 报纸 on your face: “BÀO-zhǐ! Today’s news!”

meaning: 比 (bǐ) most commonly means “to compare,” “than” (in comparisons), and “ratio.” It can also mean “to gesture” (with the hands to show shape/size). As a proper noun reading Bǐ, it abbreviates Belgium. A rare reading bī is a euphemistic variant of a vulgar word.
components: 比 is a single-component character (no separate radical plus phonetic inside). Visually, it looks like two things side‑by‑side, one slightly higher than the other. This side‑by‑side image reflects its core idea: putting two things together to compare or measure between them.

examples.zh: 这本书比那本贵。
examples.pinyin: Zhè běn shū bǐ nà běn guì.
examples.en: This book is more expensive than that one.

examples.zh: 今天比昨天冷多了。
examples.pinyin: Jīntiān bǐ zuótiān lěng duō le.
examples.en: Today is much colder than yesterday.

examples.zh: 一比二，这个比分我们落后了。
examples.pinyin: Yī bǐ èr, zhège bǐfēn wǒmen luòhòu le.
examples.en: It’s 1 to 2; we’re behind with this score.

memoryStory: Two stubborn twins stand side‑by‑side arguing whose hair is taller. They keep edging up and down, “I’m higher! I’m higher!” Their parents shout “不要比了!” (Stop comparing!). The rising‑falling 3rd tone bǐ matches their up‑and‑down, dramatic comparing.
imagePrompt: Two stylized human figures in a neon sci‑fi city stand side‑by‑side under holographic height bars, a glowing line comparing their heights. Futuristic grids and floating ratio graphs connect them, emphasizing comparison and measurement, no text.
rawDictEntry: 比 比 [Bǐ] /Belgium/Belgian/abbr. for 比利時|比利时[Bǐ lì shí]/

meaning: 别 (bié) most commonly means “don’t …!” (used to tell someone not to do something). It can also mean “other; another; different,” and as a verb it can mean “to part; to separate; to distinguish.” A less common reading is biè, “to make someone change their ways or opinions.”
components: 别 is ⿰另刂: 另 (lìng, other/another) on the left and 刂 (dāo, knife) on the right, the ‘knife’ radical. Visually, it’s like using a knife to cut something away from the rest, creating something “separate, other,” and by extension the idea of stopping or forbidding: “Don’t!”

examples.zh: 别说话，老师来了。
examples.pinyin: Bié shuōhuà, lǎoshī lái le.
examples.en: Don’t talk, the teacher is coming.

examples.zh: 我还有别的事情要做。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ hái yǒu bié de shìqing yào zuò.
examples.en: I still have other things to do.

examples.zh: 我们在这里分别吧。
examples.pinyin: Wǒmen zài zhèlǐ fēnbié ba.
examples.en: Let’s part ways here.

memoryStory: Imagine a futuristic cafeteria where robots line up. One robot (另, “other”) tries to sneak an extra dessert. A laser knife (刂) pops out of the counter, cutting off the dessert tray and a loud voice shouts “别吃！Bié chī! Don’t eat!” Now you remember 别 = “don’t / other / separate.”
imagePrompt: In a neon-lit futuristic cafeteria, a robot reaches for an extra glowing dessert. A vertical laser-knife barrier blocks its hand, clearly separating one dessert from the others. The scene shows separation and a clear “don’t” feeling, with holographic networks glowing in the background.

meaning: 长 has two common readings. cháng: long; length; for a long time; strong point, forte; to be good at. zhǎng: to grow; to develop; to increase; to rise (like prices); elder; senior; chief; head (as in 校长 ‘principal’).
components: 长 is itself a simple character component. The top strokes can suggest something stretching out, and the lower hook looks like a leg or tail extending further. Visually, it evokes something becoming longer or growing, which connects both to the idea of length (cháng) and to growing or seniority (zhǎng).

examples.zh: 这条河很长。
examples.pinyin: Zhè tiáo hé hěn cháng.

examples.zh: 他是公司的总长。

examples.zh: 孩子们长得很快。

meaning: To sing a song; to sing in general, whether alone, with friends, on stage, or at karaoke.
components:
唱: ⿰口昌. 左边「口」means mouth, related to speaking or making sounds. 右边「昌」originally shows two suns, suggesting brightness and flourishing—here it hints at loud, resonant sound. Together, 唱 is using the mouth to produce strong, clear sounds: to sing.
歌: ⿰哥欠. 左边「哥」means elder brother and also serves as a phonetic hint (gē). 右边「欠」shows a person with an open mouth, originally related to yawning or breathing out, later extended to actions involving the mouth like singing. Together, 歌 is a sound produced with the mouth: a song.
Combined, 唱歌 literally means “to sing (唱) a song (歌).”

examples.zh: 她每天洗澡的时候都会唱歌。
examples.pinyin: Tā měitiān xǐzǎo de shíhou dōu huì chànggē.
examples.en: She sings every day when she takes a shower.

examples.zh: 周末我们去KTV唱歌吧！
examples.pinyin: Zhōumò wǒmen qù KTV chànggē ba!
examples.en: Let’s go sing at KTV this weekend!

examples.zh: 他唱歌唱得很好听。
examples.pinyin: Tā chànggē chàng de hěn hǎotīng.
examples.en: He sings very well.

memoryStory: Picture your 哥 (gē, big brother) on a glowing stage with two blazing suns 昌 above him. His 口 (mouth) is so wide he almost 欠 (yawns) the stars out of the sky as he belts out a song. That’s 唱歌 chàng gē—singing a song so bright it needs two suns.
imagePrompt: Futuristic karaoke stage on a floating platform, a person with a glowing open mouth singing, sound waves as neon networks in the air, two bright suns above forming a halo, holographic musical notes streaming into a starry, cyberpunk city skyline.
rawDictEntry: 唱歌 唱歌 [chàng gē] /to sing a song/

meaning: to go out; to come out; to exit; to appear or arise; to occur; to produce or yield; to go beyond or exceed; used after a verb to indicate outward direction or a positive result; classifier for plays, operas, or chapters in classical novels.
components: 出 is written as ⿱屮凵. The top part 屮 looks like a plant sprout pushing upward. The bottom part 凵 is like an open container or a mouth-shaped pit. Together, a sprout coming out of an open container or ground vividly suggests “to come out, to go out.”

examples.zh: 他早上六点出门上班。
examples.pinyin: Tā zǎoshang liù diǎn chūmén shàngbān.
examples.en: He goes out the door at six in the morning to go to work.

examples.zh: 太阳出来了，天气变暖和了。
examples.pinyin: Tàiyáng chūlai le, tiānqì biàn nuǎnhuo le.
examples.en: The sun came out, and the weather became warmer.

examples.zh: 这家公司今年出了很多新产品。
examples.pinyin: Zhè jiā gōngsī jīnnián chūle hěn duō xīn chǎnpǐn.
examples.en: This company has brought out many new products this year.

memoryStory: Imagine a tiny plant sprout (屮) trapped in a box-shaped pit (凵). It yells “chū!” and rockets OUT of the box, flying so high it goes beyond the clouds. Every time you say chū, picture that sprout dramatically escaping its container.
imagePrompt: A small green sprout bursting upward out of a dark, box-like pit in the ground, glowing with energy. Futuristic neon grid landscape, digital networks radiating from the sprout as it emerges into bright light, no text.
rawDictEntry: 出 出 [chū] /to go out; to come out/to arise; to occur/to produce; to yield/to go beyond; to exceed/(used after a verb to indicate an outward direction or a positive result)/classifier for dramas, plays, operas etc/

meaning: To wear or put on clothes; to be dressed in something; to bore or pierce through; to perforate; to penetrate; to pass through or go through (e.g., a tunnel, a wall, space); to thread something through.
components: 穿 is ⿱穴牙: 上面是「穴」(xuè), 意为洞、洞穴、空处；下面是「牙」(yá)，本义是牙齿，也可联想成坚硬、能咬穿的东西。合在一起，可以想成用坚硬的“牙”从“洞”里穿过去——既有“钻洞、穿透”的意思，也引申为“穿在身上、穿过某处”。

examples.zh: 今天太冷了，你多穿一件衣服吧。
examples.pinyin: Jīntiān tài lěng le, nǐ duō chuān yí jiàn yīfu ba.
examples.en: It’s really cold today, put on one more layer of clothing.

examples.zh: 火车穿过山洞，只用了几分钟。
examples.pinyin: Huǒchē chuānguò shāndòng, zhǐ yòng le jǐ fēnzhōng.
examples.en: The train passed through the tunnel in just a few minutes.

examples.zh: 他把绳子穿进了针孔一样小的洞里。
examples.pinyin: Tā bǎ shéngzi chuān jìn le zhēnkǒng yíyàng xiǎo de dòng lǐ.

meaning: 船 (chuán): boat, ship, or vessel used for traveling or transporting goods on water. Commonly used for anything from small boats to large ships. Measure words: 条 (tiáo), 艘 (sōu), 只 (zhī).
components:
船 is composed of 舟 and 𠘧 + 口.
- 舟: the boat radical, picturing a small boat or canoe. It gives the basic idea of something that floats on water.
- 𠘧 + 口 (stacked on top of each other): looks like people and a mouth on the boat, suggesting passengers or crew talking or shouting. Together, the right side hints at people and activity on the boat.
Overall, the left side (舟) shows “boat,” and the right side suggests people/noise on it, reinforcing the idea of a boat carrying people.

examples.zh: 这条船要开到对岸去。
examples.pinyin: Zhè tiáo chuán yào kāi dào duì'àn qù.
examples.en: This boat is going to sail to the opposite shore.

examples.zh: 他们坐船去小岛旅行。
examples.pinyin: Tāmen zuò chuán qù xiǎo dǎo lǚxíng.
examples.en: They take a boat to travel to the small island.

examples.zh: 港口里停着很多大船和小船。
examples.pinyin: Gǎngkǒu lǐ tíng zhe hěn duō dà chuán hé xiǎo chuán.
examples.en: Many big ships and small boats are docked in the harbor.

rawDictEntry: 舩 船 [chuán] /variant of 船[chuán]/

meaning: 次 (cì): a measure word for the number of times an action happens; also means order, sequence, next in sequence, second, secondary or of lower quality (e.g., substandard). Commonly used to count events or occurrences.
components:
次 is ⿰冫欠.
- 冫 (bīng): “ice.” Visually two ice-drops; suggests cold, time passing, or something repeated and regular, like drips.
- 欠 (qiàn): “to owe, to yawn.” The picture of a person with an open mouth, suggesting a repeated action (breathing, yawning) or something not yet complete.
Together: like cold drops and repeated yawns—things that happen again and again in sequence, hinting at “times” and “next occurrences.”

examples.zh: 我去过中国两次。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ qù guò Zhōngguó liǎng cì.
examples.en: I have been to China twice.

examples.zh: 这次考试很重要。
examples.pinyin: Zhè cì kǎoshì hěn zhòngyào.
examples.en: This exam is very important.

examples.zh: 下次见面是什么时候？

examples.en: When is the next time we meet?

imagePrompt: Futuristic sci-fi lab corridor made of glowing ice panels. A person walks through, and each step triggers a bright pulse along a numbered path: first, second, third. Floating holographic droplets fall in sequence, showing repeated events along a glowing network grid.

meaning: From; via; through; to follow; to obey; to engage in (a job or activity). Also used in patterns like “从不” (never) and “从小” (since childhood). As a surname, it is read Cóng.
components: 从 is ⿰人人: two 人 (person) side by side. One person walks behind the other → following someone, moving from one place/person to another → “from, follow, obey.” The doubled person shape hints at relationships and going along with others.

examples.zh: 我从北京来。

examples.zh: 请从这儿开始读。

meaning: 错 most often means “wrong, mistaken, incorrect” (e.g., 做错, 错误). It can also mean a specific “mistake, error,” or describe things that are “interlocking, staggered, alternating” (like staggered floors or crisscrossed structures). In older or specialized uses, it can mean “to miss, let slip, evade,” or “to inlay with metal, to polish, to grind.” As a surname it is read Cuò.

meaning: “但是” is a conjunction meaning “but, however, yet.” It links two clauses where the second contrasts, limits, or softens the first. It’s very common in spoken and written Chinese and often appears near the start of the second clause.
components:
但: ⿰亻旦 — Left 亻 is the “person” radical, right 旦 shows the sun rising over the horizon, suggesting “daybreak, dawn.” Together, 但 originally related to a single or only instance, now used in words like “but.”
是: ⿱日𤴓 — Top 日 is “sun; day.” Bottom 𤴓 is a component related to “correct, right.” Combined, 是 means “to be; yes; correct.”

Putting them together: 但是 literally looks like “a person at dawn” + “is,” giving the feeling of someone starting to agree, then turning to say what actually is the case — a contrast: “but, however.”

meaning: 到 (dào): to reach; to arrive; to go to; to leave for; to (a place); until (a time); up to (a point); also used as a verb complement indicating successfully arriving at a place or achieving a result; by extension, thorough, considerate, or fully done.

meaning:
得 has several common uses:
1) dé – to obtain, get, gain; to catch (a disease); to be pleased or proud; proper, suitable, ready, finished.
2) de – structural particle used after a verb or adjective to link it with a following phrase that shows degree, result, or possibility (e.g., 走得快 ‘walk quickly’).
3) děi – must, have to, need to.
4) dè – rare pronunciation, as in 得瑟 (dè se), to show off / act smug.
components:
得 = ⿰彳 + 㝵
- 彳 (chì): “step” or “walking” radical, often related to movement, actions, or behavior.
- 㝵 (dé): phonetic component giving the sound; it contains elements like 日 (sun/day) and 寸 (inch/hand/action), hinting at something achieved or obtained through concrete actions.
Together: step (彳) + phonetic 㝵 → through actions and steps, you ‘get/obtain’ something, and can describe *how* you do it (structural particle).

examples.en: I have to leave earlier, otherwise I won’t catch the bus.

meaning:
得 has several common uses:
1) dé – to obtain, get, gain, achieve; to catch (a disease); to be suitable or proper; to be proud or contented; to allow or permit; ready/finished.
2) de – structural particle after a verb or adjective, linking it to a phrase of result, degree, or possibility (e.g., 走得快, 好得多).
3) děi – must, have to, need to.
4) dè – used in the slangy word 得瑟 (dèse), meaning to show off / act smug.
components:
得 = ⿰彳 + 㝵
- 彳 (chì): the “step”/“walk” radical, often related to movement, actions, or going somewhere.
- 㝵 (dé, phonetic): gives the sound and also hints at “obtaining/achieving.”
Together: you take steps (彳) and finally obtain/achieve (㝵) something → “to get, to attain,” and from that comes the grammar use (linking what you do to how well you do it).

meaning: Waiter, waitress, attendant, or customer service staff; a person whose job is to provide services to customers in places like restaurants, hotels, shops, or call centers.
components:
服 (fú): ⿰月𠬝. 月 originally relates to “flesh/body,” and 𠬝 suggests “to submit/obey,” so 服 carries ideas of serving, clothing, obeying.
务 (wù): ⿱夂力. 夂 is a person moving, and 力 means “strength, effort.” Together suggest actively working or handling affairs → 务 “affairs, duty, service.”
员 (yuán): ⿱口贝. 口 is a mouth, 贝 is a shell/money, historically linked to value and trade. Combined, 员 suggests a person counted as a member, staff, or employee.
Put together, 服务员 literally feels like “service-duty staff member” → someone whose duty is to serve customers.

meaning: 1) to tell; to inform; to let someone know. 2) in legal contexts, to press charges or file a complaint against someone.
components: 告: Written as ⿱𠂒口. The top part (𠂒) looks like a person standing or a raised hand, and the bottom 口 is a mouth. Together, it suggests someone standing and speaking out loudly—announcing or telling. 诉: Written as ⿰讠斥. The left side 讠 is the “speech/words” radical, related to talking, language, or saying. The right side 斥 suggests rebuking or accusing. Combined, 诉 has the sense of speaking out a complaint or accusation. 告 + 诉 together emphasize speaking out information or complaints—either simply telling someone something or formally accusing someone.

examples.zh: 有事记得告诉我。
examples.pinyin: Yǒu shì jìdé gàosu wǒ.
examples.en: If anything comes up, remember to let me know.

examples.zh: 他没告诉父母就出国了。
examples.pinyin: Tā méi gàosu fùmǔ jiù chūguó le.
examples.en: He went abroad without telling his parents.

examples.zh: 如果有人欺负你，一定要告诉老师。
examples.pinyin: Rúguǒ yǒu rén qīfu nǐ, yídìng yào gàosu lǎoshī.
examples.en: If someone bullies you, you must tell the teacher.

memoryStory: In a neon-lit future classroom, a robot student raises its metal hand (告) and opens a glowing mouth to speak. Laser words (讠) shoot out, loudly accusing a naughty drone (斥). Whether it’s sharing news or filing a complaint, this robot always “gàosu” the teacher.
imagePrompt: Futuristic classroom with a humanoid robot student standing, hand raised, glowing mouth open, sending bright speech beams toward a small misbehaving drone. Holographic networks and neon circuits connect their heads, symbolizing sharing information or reporting someone.
rawDictEntry: 告訴 告诉 [gào sù] /to press charges; to file a complaint/

meaning: 哥哥 means “older brother,” referring to a male sibling who is older than the speaker. It can also be used more loosely for an older male friend or young man in casual, friendly address, depending on context.
components: 哥哥 is two copies of 哥. The character 哥 is written as ⿱可可, literally “可” (kě) stacked on top of another “可.” 可 originally shows a mouth and something possible or permitted. Two identical blocks (可 + 可) give a feeling of repetition or ‘double.’ Doubling 哥 visually suggests ‘big brother, big brother’—the familiar, affectionate way to say older brother.

examples.zh: 我哥哥比我大三岁。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ gēge bǐ wǒ dà sān suì.
examples.en: My older brother is three years older than me.

examples.zh: 哥哥每天送我去学校。
examples.pinyin: Gēge měitiān sòng wǒ qù xuéxiào.
examples.en: My older brother takes me to school every day.

examples.zh: 那个哥哥人很好，帮了我们很多忙。
examples.pinyin: Nàge gēge rén hěn hǎo, bāngle wǒmen hěn duō máng.
examples.en: That older guy is very nice; he helped us a lot.

memoryStory: Imagine two identical cool guys named “Ke” standing one on top of the other, forming a human totem pole. They both shout in a high, long “gēēē” tone (first tone) and insist, “We’re your older brothers!” Double Ke = 哥哥, your older brother.
imagePrompt: In a neon-lit futuristic city, two slightly older boys stand protectively in front of a smaller child. Their silhouettes glow with blue circuit-like patterns linking them together, hinting at family bonds in a sci‑fi networked world. No text, clear focus on the two older brothers.
rawDictEntry: 哥哥 哥哥 [gē ge] /older brother/CL:個|个[gè],位[wèi]/

meaning: 给 (gěi) primarily means “to give,” “for,” or “for the benefit of.” It’s used when giving something to someone, doing something for someone, or marking the recipient in a sentence. In some structures it can function like the passive marker 被 or the disposal marker 把. A rarer reading jǐ means “to supply, to provide.”
components:
给 = ⿰纟 + 合
- 纟: the “silk” radical, linked to threads, connections, and giving or transferring things.
- 合: means “to combine, to join, to fit together.”
Put together: threads (纟) come together (合) — things are brought together and passed on, like giving something to someone.

examples.zh: 请给我一杯水。
examples.pinyin: Qǐng gěi wǒ yì bēi shuǐ.
examples.en: Please give me a glass of water.

examples.zh: 我给你打电话。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ gěi nǐ dǎ diànhuà.
examples.en: I’ll call you. (Literally: I give you a phone call.)

examples.zh: 妈妈给孩子买了新衣服。
examples.pinyin: Māma gěi háizi mǎi le xīn yīfu.
examples.en: Mom bought new clothes for the child.

memoryStory: A tailor made of SILK (纟) holds a box labeled “ALL TOGETHER” (合). Every time someone walks by, he shouts, “I GIVE you one thread!” and tosses them a glowing silk thread. The third tone gěi dips like his dramatic bow as he gives it away.
imagePrompt: Futuristic city street of glowing silk threads connecting people. At the center, a robot tailor made of shimmering silk hands a bright thread to a child, joining them into a luminous network. Neon colors, holographic lines forming a web of giving, no text.
rawDictEntry: 給 给 [gěi] /to/for/for the benefit of/to give/to allow/to do sth (for sb)/(grammatical equivalent of 被)/(grammatical equivalent of 把)/(sentence intensifier)/

meaning: Public bus; a large motor vehicle that follows fixed routes and schedules to carry many passengers in a city or between towns. Measure words: 辆 (liàng) for vehicles, 班 (bān) for scheduled bus services.
components:
公: ⿱八厶 — “八” (eight, split) over “厶” (private), together suggesting something made not-private → public.
共: ⿱龷八 — “龷” (stacked lines, together) plus “八” (separate), meaning things joined and shared → together, common.
汽: ⿰氵气 — “氵” (water radical) + “气” (air, gas) → watery gas, steam, implying fuel/engine → motorized.
车: 车 — pictograph of a cart with wheels → vehicle.
Putting it together: 公 + 共 (public, shared) + 汽 (motor fuel/steam) + 车 (vehicle) → a shared, public, motorized vehicle: a public bus.

examples.zh: 我每天坐公共汽车去上班。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ měitiān zuò gōnggòng qìchē qù shàngbān.
examples.en: I take the bus to work every day.

examples.zh: 这辆公共汽车太挤了，我们等下一班吧。
examples.pinyin: Zhè liàng gōnggòng qìchē tài jǐ le, wǒmen děng xià yì bān ba.
examples.en: This bus is too crowded; let's wait for the next one.

examples.zh: 在大城市里，公共汽车非常方便又便宜。
examples.pinyin: Zài dà chéngshì lǐ, gōnggòng qìchē fēicháng fāngbiàn yòu piányi.
examples.en: In big cities, buses are very convenient and cheap.

memoryStory: Two 公公 (public grandpas) decide to 共同 (share together) one huge 汽车. They fill it with water and gas (汽) and it transforms into a giant talking 车 that only moves when it’s full of people. It shouts in a high "gōnggòng qìchē!" tone every time more passengers get on.
imagePrompt: Futuristic city street with a long, sleek public bus made of glowing glass and metal, filled with many passengers. Transparent sides show people inside. Neon networks of light connect bus stops along the road. Night scene, sci‑fi cyberpunk style, no text.
rawDictEntry: 公共汽車 公共汽车 [gōng gòng qì chē] /bus/CL:輛|辆[liàng],班[bān]/

meaning: Kilogram (kg), the standard metric unit of mass/weight, equal to 1,000 grams. Used to measure the weight of things like people, food, luggage, and many everyday objects.
components:
公: written as ⿱八厶. Originally related to the idea of being public or shared, and here it suggests something official or standard, like a public standard.
斤: written as ⿸𠂆丅. 斤 is an ancient axe and also a traditional unit of weight. In modern Chinese, it still means a unit of weight (half a kilogram in Mainland China). 
Together, 公斤 literally means “public/standard weight unit,” i.e., the official metric kilogram.

examples.zh: 这个西瓜有三公斤重。
examples.pinyin: Zhè gè xīguā yǒu sān gōngjīn zhòng.
examples.en: This watermelon weighs three kilograms.

examples.zh: 行李不能超过二十公斤。
examples.pinyin: Xínglǐ bù néng chāoguò èrshí gōngjīn.
examples.en: The luggage cannot exceed twenty kilograms.

examples.zh: 我想买一公斤苹果。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ xiǎng mǎi yì gōngjīn píngguǒ.
examples.en: I’d like to buy one kilogram of apples.

memoryStory: Imagine a 公 (public) robot judge in a futuristic market. Everyone must weigh their food on his giant 斤 (axe-shaped) scale. He shouts in a high, even gōng tone, “Only 公斤 allowed!” Every item must be exactly one shiny kilogram to pass.
imagePrompt: Futuristic open market with a sleek robot judge standing by a glowing, axe-shaped scale. On the scale sits a large fruit labeled only by glowing weight bars, clearly showing one heavy unit. Neon networks and holographic weight lines connect items around, emphasizing standardized weight.
rawDictEntry: 公斤 公斤 [gōng jīn] /kilogram (kg)/

meaning: 公司 means a company, firm, or corporation — an organized business entity where people work together to provide products or services. It can be any size, from a small family firm to a large multinational corporation.
components:
公司 is made of two characters:
- 公 (gōng): written as ⿱八厶. 公 originally suggests something public or shared, like “public, common.” Think of things that belong to everyone.
- 司 (sī): written as ⿹𠃌𠮛. 司 originally has the idea of managing, being in charge, or an office/department.
Putting them together: 公 (public/shared) + 司 (to manage/office) → an office that manages public or shared affairs → a company, firm, corporation.

examples.zh: 我在一家美国公司工作。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ zài yì jiā Měiguó gōngsī gōngzuò.
examples.en: I work at an American company.

examples.zh: 这家公司有很多外国员工。
examples.pinyin: Zhè jiā gōngsī yǒu hěn duō wàiguó yuángōng.
examples.en: This company has many foreign employees.

examples.zh: 他想自己开公司，当老板。
examples.pinyin: Tā xiǎng zìjǐ kāi gōngsī, dāng lǎobǎn.
examples.en: He wants to start his own company and be the boss.

memoryStory: Imagine a huge futuristic office in space. 公 (public) means everyone in the galaxy can enter, and 司 (to manage) is a stressed alien manager with eight arms stamping documents. This space-office that manages things for everyone is your 公司 (gōngsī), a company.
imagePrompt: A futuristic glass office tower floating in space, filled with tiny glowing workers at desks connected by bright digital networks, a multi-armed alien manager overseeing holographic charts, starry background, sleek sci‑fi corporate style, no text.
rawDictEntry: 公司 公司 [gōng sī] /company; firm; corporation/CL:家[jiā]/

meaning: 贵 means “expensive, costly” and by extension “valuable, precious.” In more formal or polite usage it can also mean “honorable, noble, of high status,” and as a prefix it serves as an honorific meaning “your” (as in your esteemed…). It is also used in the proper noun Guì (short for Guizhou Province).
components: 贵 is written as ⿱𠀐贝. The bottom part 贝 (bèi) is the ‘shell’ component, originally cowrie shells, which were used as money, so it often relates to value, wealth, or trade. The top part 𠀐 is a structural component that can be seen as emphasizing or marking something as special or elevated. Put together, something marked above the shell-money suggests something of high price or great value → 贵, “expensive; precious; noble.”

examples.zh: 这件衣服太贵了，我买不起。
examples.pinyin: Zhè jiàn yīfu tài guì le, wǒ mǎi bù qǐ.
examples.en: This piece of clothing is too expensive; I can’t afford it.

examples.zh: 时间比金钱更贵重。
examples.pinyin: Shíjiān bǐ jīnqián gèng guìzhòng.
examples.en: Time is more precious than money.

examples.zh: 请问贵姓？
examples.pinyin: Qǐngwèn guì xìng?
examples.en: May I ask your honorable surname? / What is your surname, please?

memoryStory: On a neon-lit future street, a vendor sells glowing shell-coins (贝) as luxury jewelry. Above them, a big hovering crown-shaped sign (𠀐) flashes, “VIP ONLY.” You gasp at the price: these crowned shells are so 贵 (guì) that only nobles can buy them.
imagePrompt: Futuristic street market at night, a stall selling large glowing seashells as luxury items. Above the shells, a hovering crown-shaped hologram sign indicates high status and high price. Sleek sci‑fi city background with light networks in the sky, no text.
rawDictEntry: 貴 贵 [Guì] /abbr. for Guizhou Province 貴州|贵州[Guì zhōu]/

meaning:
还 has two common readings:
1) hái – “still; yet; even; in addition; fairly.” It describes something continuing, or adds extra degree/information. 
2) huán – “to return; to give back; to pay back,” especially money, books, or items you borrowed.
components:
还 is written as ⿺辶不.
- 辶 (chuò) “walk, movement, road” on the left: suggests walking, going, a process continuing or returning.
- 不 (bù) “not” on the right: a block or obstacle.
Idea: you walk (辶) but are blocked (不), so you must either KEEP GOING (hái: still, yet) or TURN BACK / RETURN (huán: give back, pay back). The form nicely covers both senses: ongoing action and returning something.

examples.zh: 他还在办公室工作。
examples.pinyin: Tā hái zài bàngōngshì gōngzuò.
examples.en: He is still working in the office.

examples.zh: 这本书我明天还给你。
examples.pinyin: Zhè běn shū wǒ míngtiān huán gěi nǐ.
examples.en: I’ll return this book to you tomorrow.

examples.zh: 这个菜还不错。
examples.pinyin: Zhège cài hái búcuò.
examples.en: This dish is pretty good / not bad at all.

memoryStory: A guy is walking along a glowing futuristic road (辶) when a giant neon “NO” sign (不) blocks him. He sighs: “I’m STILL not there yet (hái)!” Then he remembers he forgot to RETURN (huán) his robot friend’s battery, so he turns around to give it back.
imagePrompt: Futuristic neon city street with a glowing, curving road leading forward. A traveler stops at a huge red holographic “block” barrier. Behind him, identical glowing items lie in a pile he must return. Network-like light paths connect road, barrier, and items in a sci‑fi style.
rawDictEntry: 還 还 [Huán] /surname Huan/

meaning: Child; kid; a young person who is not yet an adult. It can refer to someone’s son or daughter, or children in general. Often used in everyday speech to talk about kids, parenting, or someone acting childishly.
components:
孩: ⿰子亥 — On the left is 子 (child), directly hinting at the meaning. On the right is 亥, originally a Chinese zodiac sign, here mainly a phonetic part giving the sound “hái.”
子: A pictograph of a small child with arms out, meaning “child, son.”
Together, 孩子 literally combines characters related to “child,” strongly reinforcing the idea of a kid.

examples.zh: 这个孩子很聪明。
examples.pinyin: Zhège háizi hěn cōngmíng.
examples.en: This child is very smart.

examples.zh: 她有两个孩子，一个男孩，一个女孩。
examples.pinyin: Tā yǒu liǎng gè háizi, yí gè nánhái, yí gè nǚhái.
examples.en: She has two children, one boy and one girl.

examples.zh: 别像孩子一样发脾气。
examples.pinyin: Bié xiàng háizi yíyàng fāpíqi.
examples.en: Don’t throw a tantrum like a child.

memoryStory: Imagine a giant talking baby (子) riding a rocket shaped like the zodiac sign 亥, crying “hái— hái—!” as it zooms around a playground in space. Wherever the rocket-baby flies, dozens of kids (孩子) float after it in zero gravity, giggling.
imagePrompt: In a futuristic playground on a space station, several small children float in zero gravity, laughing and chasing glowing toy planets connected by light networks. A big window shows Earth and stars outside, with soft neon colors and minimal background detail.
rawDictEntry: 孩子 孩子 [hái zi] /child/

meaning: 好吃 has two common readings: (1) hǎo chī – tasty, delicious, pleasant to eat; (2) hào chī – to be fond of eating, gluttonous, having a big appetite or a weakness for food.
components:
好: 女 (woman) + 子 (child) → together suggests “good, well, to like.”
吃: 口 (mouth) + 乞 (beg/request) → a mouth begging or asking for food → to eat.
好吃: something the mouth “begs for” because it is “good,” or a person who really “likes to eat.”

examples.zh: 这家店的饺子特别好吃。
examples.pinyin: Zhè jiā diàn de jiǎozi tèbié hǎochī.
examples.en: The dumplings at this place are especially delicious.

examples.zh: 他太好吃了，看到零食就停不下来。
examples.pinyin: Tā tài hàochī le, kàndào língshí jiù tíng bù xiàlái.
examples.en: He’s such a glutton; once he sees snacks, he just can’t stop.

examples.zh: 这个蛋糕看起来很好吃，你要不要来一块？
examples.pinyin: Zhège dàngāo kàn qǐlái hěn hǎochī, nǐ yào bu yào lái yí kuài?
examples.en: This cake looks really tasty, do you want a piece?

memoryStory: A woman (女) and her child (子) walk past a talking mouth (口) that begs (乞) for food. They hand it some noodles; the mouth shouts, “Hǎo chī! So delicious!” Then it keeps begging for more like a total glutton (hào chī), never stopping.
imagePrompt: In a neon-lit sci‑fi street, a giant holographic mouth with robotic chopsticks begs for glowing noodles from a smiling woman and child. Energy noodles form a network of light lines, connecting bowls and mouths, showing irresistible, futuristic deliciousness. No text.
rawDictEntry: 好吃 好吃 [hǎo chī] /tasty; delicious/

meaning:
号 has two main readings:
- hào: ordinal number, date of the month, mark or sign, business name, size, ship suffix, bugle call, assumed name; also used as a classifier for people (e.g., room numbers).
- háo: to roar or cry out loudly (often with emotion or grief).
components:
号 = ⿱口 + 丂
- 口 (kǒu): mouth. Suggests speaking, shouting, or making sounds.
- 丂 (kǎo, here as a component): a bent or obstructed shape, often just a phonetic part. Here it helps give the sound (hào / háo) and can suggest something coming out with force.
Together: a mouth + a strong/forced sound → calling out, announcing, giving a number or signal.

examples.zh: 今天是几号？
examples.pinyin: Jīntiān shì jǐ hào?
examples.en: What is today’s date (what day of the month is it)?

examples.zh: 请报一下你的房间号。
examples.pinyin: Qǐng bào yíxià nǐ de fángjiān hào.
examples.en: Please tell me your room number.

examples.zh: 他对着大海放声长号。
examples.pinyin: Tā duìzhe dàhǎi fàngshēng cháng háo.
examples.en: He let out a long, loud howl toward the sea.

memoryStory: Picture a giant MOUTH (口) on a spaceship, stuck behind a bent metal BAR (丂). The ship’s mouth ROARS (háo) so loudly that the sound becomes a glowing NUMBER and DATE (hào) floating over the ship: “Starship 23号.” Now you remember both the roaring and the numbering meanings.
imagePrompt: In a neon-lit sci‑fi city, a sleek starship labeled only by a glowing floating symbol hovers above a crowd. A giant stylized mouth on the ship blasts a bright sound wave that turns into numbered light-orbs, echoing like a bugle call through holographic networks.
rawDictEntry: 號 号 [háo] /roar/cry/CL:個|个[gè]/

meaning: black; dark; sinister; secret; shady; illegal; to hide something away; to vilify or slander; (loanword) to hack (in computing). Also used as an abbreviation for Heilongjiang province (黑龙江).
components: 黑 is written as ⿱⑧灬. The top part “⑧” looks like a pattern or markings, originally representing something covered or stained. The bottom “灬” is the ‘fire’ component, often seen under characters. Together, imagine something burned or scorched by fire until it becomes completely black.

examples.zh: 今天的夜空很黑，看不见星星。
examples.pinyin: Jīntiān de yèkōng hěn hēi, kàn bùjiàn xīngxing.
examples.en: The night sky is very dark today; you can’t see the stars.

examples.zh: 他喜欢穿黑衣服。
examples.pinyin: Tā xǐhuan chuān hēi yīfu.
examples.en: He likes to wear black clothes.

examples.zh: 这些是黑软件，不要下载。
examples.pinyin: Zhèxiē shì hēi ruǎnjiàn, bú yào xiàzǎi.
examples.en: This is illegal (pirated) software; don’t download it.

memoryStory: A hacker named Hēi (hēi, first tone) burns all the lights with a ring of fire (灬) so the whole city turns pitch black. On the rooftop, he paints a big “⑧” symbol in the darkness as his secret, shady signature.
imagePrompt: A futuristic cyberpunk city at night, all lights suddenly off, buildings silhouetted in deep black. On a rooftop, glowing orange embers form a stylized ‘⑧’ above four small flames, hinting at fire beneath a blackened sky, with faint digital networks flickering in the darkness.
rawDictEntry: 黑 黑 [Hēi] /abbr. for Heilongjiang province 黑龍江|黑龙江[Hēi lóng jiāng]/

meaning: Red; also extended to mean popular, favored, successful, or revolutionary (as in communist or radical movements). As a surname, it is romanized as Hong.
components: 红 is ⿰纟工. On the left, 纟 is the silk radical, related to cloth, threads, and colors (many dyes were used on silk). On the right, 工 means “work” or “labor.” Together, you can imagine someone working with silk dyes, producing strong red colors—so 红 means “red” and by extension “popular, revolutionary.”

examples.zh: 她最喜欢穿红衣服。
examples.pinyin: Tā zuì xǐhuan chuān hóng yīfu.
examples.en: She likes wearing red clothes the most.

examples.zh: 这首歌最近很红。
examples.pinyin: Zhè shǒu gē zuìjìn hěn hóng.
examples.en: This song is very popular recently.

examples.zh: 那面红旗在风中飘扬。
examples.pinyin: Nà miàn hóng qí zài fēng zhōng piāoyáng.
examples.en: That red flag is fluttering in the wind.

memoryStory: A worker (工 gōng) in an old silk (纟) factory spills a whole bucket of bright red dye on himself. He runs outside completely red, and the crowd shouts, “太红了！(tài hóng le!)” He instantly becomes a revolutionary celebrity—totally “red” and totally “popular.”
imagePrompt: A futuristic silk factory with glowing red liquid dye flowing through transparent tubes like a network. A worker stands splashed in bright red, surrounded by red flags and red silk banners, under cool metallic lighting and holographic control panels. No text.
rawDictEntry: 紅 红 [Hóng] /surname Hong/

meaning: To welcome; a warm reception or greeting given to someone arriving. It can be used as a verb (“to welcome someone”) or as an exclamation (“Welcome!”) when greeting guests, visitors, or new things.
components:
欢: ⿰又欠. The left part 又 suggests a hand or repeated action, and 欠 shows an open mouth or yawning/breathing, often linked to feelings or expressions. Together, 欢 suggests actively expressing joy and happiness.
迎: ⿺辶卬. 辶 is the ‘walking/movement’ radical, indicating motion or going to meet. 卬 shows a person raising their head. Together, 迎 suggests walking forward, lifting your head to meet someone. 欢迎 combines ‘joyful feeling’ (欢) + ‘going out to meet’ (迎) → joyfully going out to meet someone: “welcome.”

examples.zh: 欢迎你来中国！
examples.pinyin: Huān yíng nǐ lái Zhōngguó!
examples.en: Welcome to China!

examples.zh: 我们非常欢迎新同事加入团队。
examples.pinyin: Wǒmen fēicháng huān yíng xīn tóngshì jiārù tuánduì.
examples.en: We warmly welcome new colleagues to join the team.

examples.zh: 下次再来玩，我们随时欢迎你。
examples.pinyin: Xià cì zài lái wán, wǒmen suíshí huān yíng nǐ.
examples.en: Come again next time; you’re always welcome.

memoryStory: Imagine a robot host at a space station. With one HAND (又) it waves wildly, with an open MOUTH (欠) it laughs “huān!” As ships approach, it WALKS (辶) out, HEAD HELD HIGH (卬), to meet them. Joyfully going out to meet arrivals = 欢迎, huān yíng.
imagePrompt: A futuristic space-station entrance where a smiling humanoid robot walks forward with arms open to greet an arriving spaceship, glowing doors behind it wide open, soft welcoming lights and visible digital networks in the air, conveying a warm, inviting atmosphere.
rawDictEntry: 歡迎 欢迎 [huān yíng] /to welcome/welcome/

meaning: 还 has two common pronunciations: (1) hái – “still, yet, even, also, in addition, fairly,” indicating something continues or is extra; (2) huán – “to return, to give back, to pay back,” especially for borrowed things or money.
components: 还 is written as ⿺辶不. The 辶 (walk, movement) radical suggests motion or going somewhere. 不 means “not, no.” Together you can imagine movement that is “not finished yet” (hái: still, yet) or something that must “go back, not stay” (huán: to return, give back).

examples.zh: 他还在办公室工作。
examples.pinyin: Tā hái zài bàngōngshì gōngzuò.
examples.en: He is still working in the office.

examples.zh: 这本书明天记得还给我。
examples.pinyin: Zhè běn shū míngtiān jìdé huán gěi wǒ.
examples.en: Remember to return this book to me tomorrow.

examples.zh: 这个菜还不错。
examples.pinyin: Zhège cài hái búcuò.
examples.en: This dish is pretty good.

memoryStory: Picture a robot walking (辶) away with your stuff but a big red “NOT” sign (不) flashes above its head. The system says: “Item is NOT gone, it must STILL be returned.” So hái = still, and huán = give it back!
imagePrompt: Futuristic city street with glowing neon paths showing moving arrows. A small delivery robot walks away holding a borrowed book, while a red holographic ‘X’ hovers over it and a glowing arrow curves back toward the owner, suggesting the item must still be returned.
rawDictEntry: 還 还 [Huán] /surname Huan/

meaning: 回答 means “to reply; to answer” and can refer both to the act of responding (verb) and the response itself (noun), especially in conversation, messages, or test questions.
components:
回: ⿴囗口 — The outer 囗 is an enclosure, and 口 is a mouth. Together, it suggests a sound or message going around and coming back, like a reply returning to you.
答: ⿱竹合 — 竹 (bamboo) on top, 合 (to join, to fit together) below. In ancient times, answers or writings were recorded on bamboo slips that ‘fit together’. So 答 suggests “putting words together” to give an answer.

examples.zh: 请在明天之前回答我的邮件。
examples.pinyin: Qǐng zài míngtiān zhīqián huídá wǒ de yóujiàn.
examples.en: Please reply to my email before tomorrow.

examples.zh: 老师问问题，他没有回答出来。
examples.pinyin: Lǎoshī wèn wèntí, tā méiyǒu huídá chūlái.
examples.en: The teacher asked a question, but he couldn’t come up with an answer.

examples.zh: 你的回答非常有帮助。
examples.pinyin: Nǐ de huídá fēicháng yǒu bāngzhù.
examples.en: Your answer is very helpful.

memoryStory: You shout a question into a square room with a big mouth (回). Suddenly, a serious bamboo forest (竹) assembles into a talking face (合) that snaps together and loudly gives you the perfect ANSWER (回答 huídá) before vanishing back into the walls.
imagePrompt: In a glowing sci‑fi room shaped like a square enclosure, a giant floating mouth sends out neon sound waves. Across from it, bamboo rods assemble into a humanoid face that lights up and beams a bright reply back through a digital network grid.
rawDictEntry: 回答 回答 [huí dá] /to reply; to answer/reply; answer/

meaning: 机场 means “airport” or “airfield,” the place where airplanes take off and land. In modern slang, it can also mean a ‘service provider’ that offers network tools (like Shadowsocks) to bypass Internet censorship.
components:
机: ⿰木几 — left 木 (wood), often linked to tools or machines; right 几 suggests the sound and also a small table shape. Together, 机 often means “machine” or “aircraft” in this context.
场: ⿰土𠃓 — left 土 (earth, ground); right 𠃓 is a simplified component that hints at the sound and shape. 场 originally means a field or open ground, a place where activities happen.
So 机场 = 机 (airplanes, machines) + 场 (open ground/place) → the place where planes are on the ground: an airport.

examples.zh: 我明天早上要去机场接朋友。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ míngtiān zǎoshang yào qù jīchǎng jiē péngyou.
examples.en: I’m going to the airport tomorrow morning to pick up a friend.

examples.zh: 这个城市的新机场离市中心很远。
examples.pinyin: Zhège chéngshì de xīn jīchǎng lí shìzhōngxīn hěn yuǎn.
examples.en: The new airport in this city is far from the downtown area.

examples.zh: 他在机场买了一杯咖啡等登机。
examples.pinyin: Tā zài jīchǎng mǎi le yì bēi kāfēi děng dēngjī.
examples.en: He bought a cup of coffee at the airport while waiting to board.

memoryStory: Imagine a giant wooden robot (机) running late for a flight. It sprints across a huge dirt field (场), waving its boarding pass. The whole ‘field of machines’ is actually the airport. As it runs, it shouts “jī-chǎng, jī-chǎng!” in panic.

meaning: 鸡蛋 means a (chicken) egg or hen’s egg, usually the regular eggs people eat. It can refer to one egg or eggs in general, and is a very common everyday food word.
components:
鸡: ⿰又鸟. The right side 鸟 means “bird,” and the whole character 鸡 means “chicken.” Think: a specific kind of bird we raise for meat and eggs. 
蛋: ⿱疋虫. The top 疋 can suggest a lump or piece, and the bottom 虫 means “insect/bug.” Together, imagine a little creature (虫) curled up inside a lump or shell (疋) – that’s an egg with life inside. 
So 鸡蛋 is literally “chicken + egg” → chicken egg.

examples.zh: 早饭我一般吃两个鸡蛋。
examples.pinyin: Zǎofàn wǒ yìbān chī liǎng gè jīdàn.
examples.en: For breakfast I usually eat two eggs.

examples.zh: 这个鸡蛋是不是坏了？有点儿怪味。
examples.pinyin: Zhège jīdàn shì bú shì huài le? Yǒudiǎnr guài wèi.
examples.en: Is this egg bad? It smells a bit strange.

examples.zh: 他对鸡蛋过敏，只能喝牛奶。
examples.pinyin: Tā duì jīdàn guòmǐn, zhǐ néng hē niúnǎi.
examples.en: He is allergic to eggs and can only drink milk.

meaning: 件 (jiàn): a measure word (classifier) for individual items, events, and pieces of clothing; also means an item, piece, or component of something.
components: 件 is ⿰亻牛. On the left, 亻 is the “person” radical, suggesting people or human-related things. On the right, 牛 means “cow/ox,” often used phonetically here (niú → jiàn), but you can imagine a person dealing with a cow as a separate ‘item’ or ‘case’ of work.

examples.zh: 这是一件很重要的事。
examples.pinyin: Zhè shì yí jiàn hěn zhòngyào de shì.
examples.en: This is a very important matter.

examples.zh: 我买了一件新衣服。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ mǎile yí jiàn xīn yīfu.
examples.en: I bought a new piece of clothing.

examples.zh: 警察在调查一件奇怪的案件。
examples.pinyin: Jǐngchá zài diàochá yí jiàn qíguài de ànjiàn.
examples.en: The police are investigating a strange case.

memoryStory: Picture a PERSON (亻) in court leading a big COW (牛) to the witness stand. The judge says, “Next CASE, next ITEM: the cow!” Every ‘case/item’ that comes up is one 件. The flat falling tone (jiàn, 4th) is like the judge’s firm gavel strike.
imagePrompt: In a sleek sci‑fi courtroom, a human in a futuristic suit leads a glowing robotic cow to stand on a platform. Around them float holographic icons, each representing a separate item or case. Neon networks connect the icons in midair, no text anywhere.

meaning: Classroom; a room specifically used for teaching and learning, usually in a school, with desks, chairs, a board, and teaching equipment.
components: 教 (jiào): ⿰孝攵. Left 孝 means “filial, respect for elders/teachers,” right 攵 is a hand holding a stick, suggesting action or instruction. Together, it hints at elders using actions to teach—thus “to teach.” 室 (shì): ⿱宀至. 宀 is a roof, meaning a building or room. 至 shows an arrow or person arriving at a point, meaning “to arrive.” Under a roof where people arrive = a specific room. 教室 literally: the room where teaching happens.

examples.zh: 我们在教室里上中文课。
examples.pinyin: Wǒmen zài jiàoshì lǐ shàng Zhōngwén kè.
examples.en: We have Chinese class in the classroom.

examples.zh: 教室里有很多桌子和椅子。
examples.pinyin: Jiàoshì lǐ yǒu hěn duō zhuōzi hé yǐzi.
examples.en: There are many desks and chairs in the classroom.

examples.zh: 下课了，学生们快快乐乐地走出教室。
examples.pinyin: Xiàkè le, xuéshēngmen kuài kuàilè lè de zǒuchū jiàoshì.
examples.en: Class is over, and the students happily walk out of the classroom.

meaning: 姐姐 means “older sister,” referring to a female sibling who is older than the speaker. It can also be used more loosely to address or refer to a slightly older young woman in a friendly or respectful way.
components: Each 姐 is composed of 女 (nǚ, woman/female) on the left and 且 (qiě) on the right. 女 indicates that the word relates to a female person. 且 originally looks like stacked pieces or a platform, and here serves as a phonetic component, giving the sound “jiě.” Together, 女 + 且 = 姐, a female-related character pronounced jiě. Doubling it (姐姐) emphasizes this role and makes it a common, affectionate word for one’s older sister.

examples.zh: 我姐姐比我大三岁。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ jiějie bǐ wǒ dà sān suì.
examples.en: My older sister is three years older than me.

examples.zh: 姐姐常常照顾我。

examples.zh: 那位服务员姐姐很热情。

examples.en: That waitress (older-sister figure) is very warm and friendly.

imagePrompt: In a neon-lit futuristic city, two slightly older teenage girls stand protectively in front of a younger child. They wear matching jackets with glowing lines like circuit networks, holding hands. Holographic family photos float around them. No text.

meaning: 介绍 means to introduce someone or something, to present a person (for a job, event, etc.), or to give an introduction or overview (such as of a topic, place, or product).
components: 介: Top part looks like a person 人 standing between two lines, suggesting being in-between or acting as a go‑between. It carries the idea of ‘between, to mediate’. 绍: 纟 is the silk/thread radical, related to lines, connections, and relationships; 召 shows sound/calling, as if calling someone over. Together, 绍 suggests ‘drawing a connection, calling someone into a relationship’. 介绍 combines ‘go‑between’ (介) + ‘connect/call’ (绍) → acting as a go‑between to connect and present people or things: to introduce.

examples.zh: 请你给我介绍一下这家公司。
examples.pinyin: Qǐng nǐ gěi wǒ jièshào yíxià zhè jiā gōngsī.
examples.en: Please introduce this company to me.

examples.zh: 他在会议上介绍了新产品。
examples.pinyin: Tā zài huìyì shàng jièshào le xīn chǎnpǐn.
examples.en: He introduced the new product at the meeting.

memoryStory: At a sci‑fi party, 介 the ‘middleman’ stands between two shy aliens. 介 grabs glowing silk threads from 绍 and throws them like lasso-lines around each alien, loudly calling their names. The bright threads pull them together as 介 shouts, “让我来介绍你们！”

meaning: 进 means to go forward, to advance, to go in, to enter, to put in, to submit, to take in, to admit, and (in mathematics) the base of a number system. It can also be a classifier for sections in a building or residential compound.
components: 进 is ⿺辶井. The left part 辶 is the “movement/walk” radical, suggesting motion or going somewhere. The right part 井 originally means “well” (a square well or orderly grid). Together, think of someone moving (辶) toward the well (井) or into an orderly area, hinting at ‘going in, entering, advancing’.

examples.zh: 请进！
examples.pinyin: Qǐng jìn!
examples.en: Please come in!

examples.zh: 他在工作上进步很快。

examples.zh: 不要往里进得太深。
examples.pinyin: Búyào wǎng lǐ jìn de tài shēn.

meaning: Near; close (in distance, time, or relationship); to approach; approximately, about.
components: 近 is ⿺辶斤. 辶 is the “walking/movement” radical, suggesting going or traveling. 斤 means “axe” or a unit of weight. Put together: walking (辶) toward the axe (斤) — you’re already very close to it.

examples.en: It’s already getting close to exam time.

meaning: 就 (jiù) is a very common word meaning: 1) then; in that case (connecting a condition to a result), 2) as soon as; immediately; right away, 3) just; simply; exactly; precisely (emphasizing or narrowing), 4) only / as few as, or conversely as many as (emphasizing quantity), 5) to approach; to go to; to engage in, 6) with regard to; concerning, and 7) in patterns like “就…也…” (even if…still…) and “不…就…” (if not A, then must be B).
components:
就 is written as ⿰京尤, a left–right structure.
- 京 (jīng): looks like a tall building or capital city. It can hint at something important or central, like a key moment.
- 尤 (yóu): originally has the idea of “especially” or “particularly,” like pointing out something exact.
Put together, you can imagine: in the ‘big city’ (京) you must react to things ‘especially, exactly’ (尤) and quickly — that’s 就: the exact moment something happens, then right away, or simply/precisely that thing.

examples.zh: 如果你想走，我就陪你一起走。
examples.pinyin: Rúguǒ nǐ xiǎng zǒu, wǒ jiù péi nǐ yìqǐ zǒu.
examples.en: If you want to leave, then I’ll go with you.

examples.zh: 他一到家就开始做饭。
examples.pinyin: Tā yí dào jiā jiù kāishǐ zuòfàn.
examples.en: As soon as he gets home, he starts cooking.

examples.zh: 这件事我就知道一个人能帮你。
examples.pinyin: Zhè jiàn shì wǒ jiù zhīdào yí ge rén néng bāng nǐ.
examples.en: For this matter, I know exactly one person who can help you.

memoryStory: In a futuristic capital city 京, a hero wears a glowing glove labeled 尤, meaning “especially.” Whenever something happens, the glove instantly flashes and teleports him THERE RIGHT AWAY. He doesn’t think, he JUST does it, THEN immediately appears at the exact spot: 就, quick and exact.
imagePrompt: Futuristic neon city skyline (京) at night. A hero with a glowing glove marked by a sharp, pointing shape (尤) teleports instantly from one rooftop to another in a flash of light, showing immediate action and precise arrival, with digital networks glowing between buildings.

meaning: 觉得 means “to feel that” or “to think that” about something. It expresses a personal feeling, impression, or opinion, often followed by an adjective, verb phrase, or full clause.
components:
觉: ⿳𭕄冖见 – The top parts (𭕄 + 冖) suggest something happening in the head or under a cover, and 见 means “to see.” Together they hint at “awareness” or “to realize/feel” through seeing or sensing.
得: ⿰彳㝵 – 彳 is the “step” radical, related to movement or action. 㝵 is a phonetic part giving the sound and can hint at “obtaining.” Together, 得 often means “to get, to obtain, to result in.”
Combined, 觉得 is like “awareness (觉) that you get (得)” → what you feel or think.

examples.zh: 我觉得这本书很好看。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ juéde zhè běn shū hěn hǎokàn.
examples.en: I think this book is very good.

examples.zh: 你觉得今天的天气怎么样？
examples.pinyin: Nǐ juéde jīntiān de tiānqì zěnme yàng?
examples.en: How do you feel about today’s weather?

examples.zh: 他觉得有点儿累，所以想休息。
examples.pinyin: Tā juéde yǒudiǎnr lèi, suǒyǐ xiǎng xiūxi.
examples.en: He feels a bit tired, so he wants to rest.

memoryStory: Under a little roof in the future, a cyber-monk suddenly SEES (见) a hologram pop up in his mind—“I FEEL this is right!” Every time he takes a STEP (彳) he GETS (得) another opinion bubble. 觉 = awareness, 得 = get → 觉得: the feelings/opinions you ‘get.’
imagePrompt: In a neon-lit futuristic city, a person stands with glowing neural circuits around their head, holographic thought bubbles showing different emotions and ideas, all connected by bright network lines, symbolizing personal feelings and opinions forming in the mind.
rawDictEntry: 覺得 觉得 [jué de] /to think that ...; to feel that .../to feel (uncomfortable etc)/

meaning: Coffee – a beverage made from roasted and ground coffee beans, usually brewed with hot water. It can also refer to coffee as a flavor (like coffee ice cream) or coffee-related drinks in general.
components: 咖: 口 (mouth) + 加 (to add). Imagine adding something into your mouth to drink. 啡: 口 (mouth) + 非 (not, wrong). The mouth + “not” suggests a strong, slightly bitter taste that’s not sweet. Together, two mouth radicals hint at a drink people keep sipping: coffee.

examples.zh: 早上不喝咖啡，我就醒不过来。
examples.pinyin: Zǎoshang bù hē kāfēi, wǒ jiù xǐng bù guòlái.
examples.en: If I don’t drink coffee in the morning, I just can’t wake up.

examples.pinyin: Zhè jiā kāfēidiàn de nátiě hěn hǎohē.

imagePrompt: A futuristic glass mug of steaming dark coffee on a glowing table, holographic coffee beans orbiting above it, with neon circuits and network lines connecting the mug to a high-tech city skyline in the background. No text.

meaning: 开始 means to begin, to start, or the beginning of something. It is used for starting actions, events, processes, or periods of time, like starting a class, a project, a relationship, or a new life phase.
components:
开: Written as ⿱一廾. The top 一 is a horizontal line; 廾 originally shows two hands. Together, 开 suggests hands opening something up, like opening a gate or starting a machine.
始: Written as ⿰女台. 女 means “woman,” and 台 originally shows a raised platform or stage. Together, 始 suggests a woman on a platform starting something important—like the beginning of a ceremony or event.
Combined, 开始 literally feels like “open the start” — to open up and let something begin.

examples.zh: 电影马上就要开始了。
examples.pinyin: Diànyǐng mǎshàng jiù yào kāishǐ le.
examples.en: The movie is about to start.

examples.zh: 从今天开始，我要每天练习中文。
examples.pinyin: Cóng jīntiān kāishǐ, wǒ yào měitiān liànxí Zhōngwén.
examples.en: Starting from today, I will practice Chinese every day.

examples.zh: 会议九点正式开始。
examples.pinyin: Huìyì jiǔ diǎn zhèngshì kāishǐ.
examples.en: The meeting officially begins at nine o’clock.

imagePrompt: A futuristic metal gate slowly opening as a lone woman steps onto a glowing platform. Energy lines and digital networks light up and spread outward the moment she steps on, symbolizing the start of an event. Neon sci‑fi colors, no text.
