meaning: To take an exam; an exam or test itself (a formal assessment of knowledge or skills), measure word: 次 (cì).
components: 考: ⿸耂丂. 耂 is a variant of 老 (old), suggesting an elder or teacher; 丂 hints at breath or effort. Together, imagine an elder testing your effort. 试: ⿰讠式. 讠 is the speech/words radical, and 式 means pattern, style, or formula. Combined, 试 means to test or try using words or set patterns, like exam questions. So 考试 is the elder testing you with patterned questions.

examples.zh: 明天我要参加汉语考试。
examples.pinyin: Míngtiān wǒ yào cānjiā Hànyǔ kǎoshì.
examples.en: Tomorrow I’m going to take a Chinese exam.

examples.zh: 这次考试很难，但是他考得很好。
examples.pinyin: Zhè cì kǎoshì hěn nán, dànshì tā kǎo de hěn hǎo.
examples.en: This exam was very difficult, but he did very well.

examples.zh: 老师说，下周有期末考试。
examples.pinyin: Lǎoshī shuō, xià zhōu yǒu qīmò kǎoshì.
examples.en: The teacher said there will be final exams next week.

memoryStory: An old, strict teacher (考) floats in a sci‑fi classroom, breathing loudly as he stares at you. With a wave of his hand, glowing word‑patterns (试) fly out and stick to your desk. He says, “Speak the right patterns or FAIL!”—that’s your kǎo‑shì exam.
imagePrompt: In a futuristic classroom, a stern elderly teacher hologram hovers over rows of students. Neon-blue exam papers float in the air, connected by glowing circuit-like networks. Students sweat as a countdown timer glows above, emphasizing a high-tech exam atmosphere.
rawDictEntry: 考試 考试 [kǎo shì] /to take an exam/exam/CL:次[cì]/

meaning: “可能” means something is possible or might happen; it can also mean “maybe / perhaps” when guessing, and as a noun it means “possibility / probability.”
components:
可: ⿹丁口 — The top 丁 looks like a nail or small bar, over 口 (mouth). Originally related to something that is ‘permitted’ or ‘can be said.’
能: ⿰䏍𫧇 — On the left 䏍 is a flesh/ability-related component, on the right 𫧇 comes from the ancient form for ‘bear’ or ‘capable beast.’ Together, 能 carries the idea of ability, capability, being able to do something.
Combined, 可能 = 可 (can, allowed) + 能 (ability) → something that can have the ability to happen = possible, might happen.

examples.zh: 今天可能会下雨，你带把伞吧。
examples.pinyin: Jīntiān kěnéng huì xiàyǔ, nǐ dài bǎ sǎn ba.
examples.en: It might rain today; you should bring an umbrella.

examples.zh: 他这么晚还没回来，可能加班了。
examples.pinyin: Tā zhème wǎn hái méi huílai, kěnéng jiābān le.
examples.en: He still isn’t back so late; he’s probably working overtime.

examples.zh: 这件事成功的可能不大。
examples.pinyin: Zhè jiàn shì chénggōng de kěnéng bú dà.
examples.en: The possibility of this succeeding is not very high.

memoryStory: A judge with a big 口 (mouth) and a 丁-shaped hammer says “可 (kě)!” to approve things. Next to him, a superhero bear labeled 能 (néng) shows off its powers. Whenever the judge says “可,” the bear might act. So 可 + 能 = kěnéng: it might happen, it’s possible.
imagePrompt: Futuristic city street under a transparent dome, half the sky sunny, half stormy. A person stands at a glowing crossroads, holographic weather icons floating above: sun, clouds, rain with question marks. Neon network lines connect possibilities in the sky, suggesting uncertainty and potential.
rawDictEntry: 可能 可能 [kě néng] /might (happen)/possible/probable/possibility/probability/maybe/perhaps/CL:個|个[gè]/

meaning: Can; may; to be allowed to; to be able to; indicates possibility or permission. In informal speech it can also mean “not bad, pretty good” when commenting on something.
components:
可以 is made of 可 and 以.
- 可 (kě): written as ⿹丁口 — a shape like 丁 over 口 (mouth). Originally related to something acceptable or allowable to the mouth, it came to mean “can, may, acceptable.”
- 以 (yǐ): a standalone character, historically meaning “to use, by means of.” It suggests a method or way of doing something.
Together, 可以 literally feels like “may use / can, by means of,” which fits its sense of having the ability or permission to do something.

examples.zh: 我可以进去吗？
examples.pinyin: Wǒ kěyǐ jìnqù ma?
examples.en: May I go in?

examples.zh: 这里的咖啡还可以。
examples.pinyin: Zhèlǐ de kāfēi hái kěyǐ.
examples.en: The coffee here is pretty good / not bad.

examples.zh: 你现在可以休息了。
examples.pinyin: Nǐ xiànzài kěyǐ xiūxi le.
examples.en: You can rest now.

memoryStory: A giant talking 口 (mouth) sits on a throne made of 丁-shaped blocks, acting as the city’s permission judge (可). People line up with gadgets they want to use (以 = “use, by means of”). When the mouth-shape shouts “可以!”, all gadgets suddenly work and everyone happily uses them.
imagePrompt: Futuristic city gate shaped like a giant glowing mouth, with a small block-shaped symbol above it. People hold devices waiting. When the gate glows green, they walk through and their devices light up, showing they are allowed to use them. Neon, sci‑fi network style.
rawDictEntry: 可以 可以 [kě yǐ] /can/may/possible/able to/not bad/pretty good/

meaning: Lesson; class; school subject; course (measure words: 门, 堂, 节). Also: to levy or charge (as in tax or fee), and a traditional term in divination contexts.
components: 课 is ⿰讠果. On the left, 讠 is the speech/words radical, related to talking, teaching, or language. On the right, 果 means fruit or result. Together: spoken words (讠) that produce a fruitful result (果) → a lesson, class, or course that bears fruit in your learning.

examples.zh: 我们今天有三节汉语课。
examples.pinyin: Wǒmen jīntiān yǒu sān jié Hànyǔ kè.
examples.en: We have three Chinese lessons today.

examples.zh: 这门课很难，但是很有意思。
examples.pinyin: Zhè mén kè hěn nán, dànshì hěn yǒuyìsi.
examples.en: This course is difficult, but very interesting.

examples.zh: 上课不要玩手机。
examples.pinyin: Shàng kè búyào wán shǒujī.
examples.en: Don’t play with your phone during class.

memoryStory: A strict robot teacher stands by a giant glowing fruit labeled “果”. Every time it speaks 讠, a slice of fruit flies into students’ brains, instantly giving them knowledge. The more “kè” (课) you attend, the more brain-fruit you collect—skip class and the fruit zaps you instead.
imagePrompt: Futuristic classroom in a neon-lit spaceship. A holographic teacher projects glowing speech symbols toward a giant floating fruit that splits into light-particles entering students’ helmets, showing knowledge transfer. Transparent screens display networks of lines connecting students’ heads, sci‑fi style, no text.
rawDictEntry: 課 课 [kè] /subject/course/CL:門|门[mén]/class/lesson/CL:堂[táng],節|节[jié]/to levy/tax/form of divination/

meaning: rapid; fast; quick; soon; almost; to make haste; sharp (like a knife or wit); straightforward; cheerful; pleased; pleasant.
components: 快 is ⿰忄夬. The left side 忄 is the “heart” radical, related to feelings and emotions. The right side 夬 gives the sound (kuài) and hints at decisiveness, like a quick, sharp action. Together: a heart that reacts quickly or feels happy and light.

examples.zh: 你走得太快了，我跟不上。
examples.pinyin: Nǐ zǒu de tài kuài le, wǒ gēn bù shàng.
examples.en: You walk too fast; I can’t keep up.

examples.zh: 时间过得真快，一下子就晚上了。
examples.pinyin: Shíjiān guò de zhēn kuài, yíxiàzi jiù wǎnshang le.
examples.en: Time really flies; it’s evening in no time.

examples.zh: 听到这个好消息，我心里很快活。
examples.pinyin: Tīngdào zhège hǎo xiāoxi, wǒ xīnlǐ hěn kuàihuó.
examples.en: Hearing this good news, I feel very happy inside.

memoryStory: A tiny heart 忄 is driving a rocket labeled 夬. It slams the launch button so decisively that the rocket shoots off super fast, making the heart shout “kuài! kuài!” as it speeds happily through space.
imagePrompt: A small glowing red heart piloting a sleek rocket, blasting forward with motion blur. Neon-blue digital stars and network lines streak past to show extreme speed. Futuristic sci‑fi style, metallic surfaces, no text.
rawDictEntry: 快 快 [kuài] /rapid/quick/speed/rate/soon/almost/to make haste/clever/sharp (of knives or wits)/forthright/plainspoken/gratified/pleased/pleasant/

meaning: 快乐 means feeling happy, joyful, delighted or pleased. It describes a positive emotional state, from simple contentment to cheerful excitement, and can be used for people, events, time periods, or wishes (like “Happy New Year”).
components: 快: 忄(heart, feelings) + 夬(a decisive action or split). Together, it suggests the heart reacting quickly or decisively—quick feelings, quick joy. 乐: originally a picture of a musical instrument, meaning music and pleasure. Over time it came to mean happiness and enjoyment. So 快乐 is like “the heart quickly reaches musical-style joy.”

examples.zh: 祝你生日快乐！
examples.pinyin: Zhù nǐ shēngrì kuàilè!
examples.en: Wish you a happy birthday!

examples.zh: 和朋友一起聊天让我很快乐。
examples.pinyin: Hé péngyǒu yìqǐ liáotiān ràng wǒ hěn kuàilè.
examples.en: Chatting with friends makes me very happy.

examples.zh: 希望你每天都很快乐。
examples.pinyin: Xīwàng nǐ měitiān dōu hěn kuàilè.
examples.en: I hope you are happy every day.

memoryStory: Your HEART (忄) makes a QUICK (快) decision: it will only work when it hears MUSIC (乐). A robot doctor plays cheerful tunes; your heart instantly starts dancing and you feel super 快乐—quick heart, musical joy, happy life.
imagePrompt: Futuristic city plaza at night, glowing network lines in the air connecting smiling people dancing. At the center, a transparent heart-shaped core pulsing with light, surrounded by floating musical instruments emitting holographic waves of color, creating an atmosphere of pure joy.
rawDictEntry: 快樂 快乐 [kuài lè] /happy; joyful/

meaning: 累 has several related meanings: (lèi) tired, weary, to strain, to wear out, to work hard; (lěi) to accumulate, to pile up, to involve or implicate, continuous or repeated; (léi) rope, to bind together, to twist around.
components: 累 is written as ⿱田糸: 上面是「田」(field), 下面是「糸」(silk, thread). 想像在田裡拉著絲線、繩子，一圈一圈地綁、反覆地做：東西被一圈圈纏起來就『累積』起來，人不停做這些事就會很『疲累』。

examples.zh: 我今天工作了一整天，真的好累。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ jīntiān gōngzuò le yī zhěng tiān, zhēn de hǎo lèi.
examples.en: I worked the whole day today; I’m really tired.

examples.zh: 這幾年他累積了很多經驗。
examples.pinyin: Zhè jǐ nián tā lěijī le hěn duō jīngyàn.
examples.en: Over the past few years he has accumulated a lot of experience.

examples.zh: 繩子一圈圈地纏在一起，越來越累。
examples.pinyin: Shéngzi yī quān quān de chán zài yìqǐ, yuè lái yuè léi.
examples.en: The rope twists around in loops, becoming more and more tightly bound.

memoryStory: 在一塊大田裡，有人用細細的絲線把雜物一圈圈綁起來「累積」成一大堆。太陽底下，他反覆地繞線、打結，汗水像線一樣往下滴，最後人和東西一起被絲線「捆」住，累得直喊：「我好累(lèi)啊！」
imagePrompt: In a futuristic rice field made of glowing circuit-tiles, a tired robot farmer drags shining silk-like cables, wrapping them in many coils around piles of objects, forming a glowing rope bundle. The robot slumps with exhaustion under a neon sun, networks of light threads crisscrossing the field.
rawDictEntry: 累 累 [lěi] /to accumulate/to involve or implicate (Taiwan pr. [lèi])/continuous/repeated/

meaning: To leave, to part from, to be away from; used to indicate distance ('from'); without, independent of; also the name of one of the Eight Trigrams (☲), symbolizing fire. As a proper noun, it can also be a surname (Lí).
components: 离 is written as ⿱㐫禸. The top part 㐫 is an old component related to beasts/ferocity in ancient forms, and the bottom 禸 originally depicted an animal’s footprint or track. Together, you can imagine a beast’s tracks moving away from somewhere — a hint of ‘leaving’ or ‘being apart’. In modern usage, 离 is a common character meaning separation or distance, even though its original ‘mythical beast’ meaning is now archaic.

examples.zh: 我家离学校很近。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ jiā lí xuéxiào hěn jìn.
examples.en: My home is very close to the school. (Literally: The distance from my home to the school is very short.)

examples.zh: 他刚离开办公室。
examples.pinyin: Tā gāng líkāi bàngōngshì.
examples.en: He just left the office.

examples.zh: 没有你，我离不开咖啡。
examples.pinyin: Méiyǒu nǐ, wǒ lí bù kāi kāfēi.
examples.en: Without you, I can’t do without coffee. (Playful use of ‘lí bù kāi’ = can’t be separated from).

memoryStory: A mythical beast (old meaning of 离) sneaks out of a futuristic city, leaving glowing footprints (禸) on the ground. Every step it takes, it gets farther and farther away. You shout “lí!” as your distance from it keeps increasing — remember: 离 = to leave, be away from.
imagePrompt: In a neon-lit futuristic city at night, a glowing mythical beast walks away, leaving bright digital footprints stretching into the distance, with two separated city towers in the background connected by a faint holographic distance line. No text.
rawDictEntry: 离 离 [chī] /mythical beast (archaic)/

meaning: 两 (liǎng) means “two, both, a couple, a few,” and is also a traditional unit of weight (tael, about 50 grams). It is most often used before measure words or classifiers, e.g., 两个人 (two people), 两杯水 (two glasses of water).
components: 两 is written as ⿱一⿻冂从. Top 一 means “one.” Below, 冂 looks like an open frame or border, and 从 shows two people standing together (one following another). Visually, you can think of “one” over “two people together,” hinting at the idea of ‘two / both.’

examples.zh: 我有两个妹妹。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ yǒu liǎng gè mèimei.
examples.en: I have two younger sisters.

examples.zh: 请给我两杯咖啡。
examples.pinyin: Qǐng gěi wǒ liǎng bēi kāfēi.
examples.en: Please give me two cups of coffee.

examples.zh: 这件衣服两百块。
examples.pinyin: Zhè jiàn yīfu liǎng bǎi kuài.
examples.en: This piece of clothing costs two hundred yuan.

memoryStory: Imagine TWO little people (从) trapped inside a big open frame (冂). A giant hand draws ONE horizontal line (一) on top and says, “You TWO must share ONE room!” They both shout in the third tone “liǎǎǎng!” as they squeeze together.
imagePrompt: Futuristic neon city street at night, two identical glowing robots standing side by side under a single horizontal light bar above them, framed by a rectangular doorway shape, emphasizing the number two. Holographic networks and circuits in the background, no text.
rawDictEntry: 兩 两 [liǎng] /two/both/some/a few/tael, unit of weight equal to 50 grams (modern) or 1⁄16 of a catty 斤[jīn] (old)/

meaning: road; path; way; route; journey; line (e.g., bus line); method or approach; sort or kind; also a surname (Lù). Often refers to both physical roads and more abstract paths in life or plans.
components: 路 is ⿰𧾷各. The left part 𧾷 is related to feet and movement, hinting at walking and traveling. The right part 各 (gè) means “each, every,” and here acts mainly as a sound component, giving the pronunciation clue and suggesting many different ways or routes.

examples.zh: 这条路通向城市中心。
examples.pinyin: Zhè tiáo lù tōngxiàng chéngshì zhōngxīn.
examples.en: This road leads to the city center.

examples.zh: 人生的路有很多选择。
examples.pinyin: Rénshēng de lù yǒu hěn duō xuǎnzé.
examples.en: There are many choices on the road of life.

examples.zh: 请问去火车站怎么走？哪路车方便？
examples.pinyin: Qǐngwèn qù huǒchēzhàn zěnme zǒu? Nǎ lù chē fāngbiàn?
examples.en: Excuse me, how do I get to the train station? Which bus route is convenient?

memoryStory: A tiny robot with FEET (𧾷) stands at a huge crossroads where EACH (各) direction is a glowing neon road. A loud GPS voice shouts “LÙ! LÙ! LÙ!” every time it chooses a new shining route to try. So 路 (lù) is the road or route you walk.
imagePrompt: Night scene: a glowing futuristic highway network seen from above, neon blue and purple roads branching like circuits. Tiny figures walk on luminous paths, flying buses glide along light-lines, all converging toward a bright central hub, suggesting many routes and journeys.
rawDictEntry: 路 路 [Lù] /surname Lu/

meaning: To travel or go on a trip for pleasure or exploration; tourism in general, including journeys, tours, and sightseeing.
components: 旅: ⿰方⿱𠂉④ — The left part 方 suggests direction or place, like heading toward somewhere; the right structure (person + strokes) can hint at people on the move. Together, 旅 gives the idea of people going to different places: a journey. 游: ⿰氵斿 — 氵 is the water radical, often related to moving, flowing, or traveling. 斿 shows a flag or banner, something that waves as you move. Combined, 游 suggests moving or wandering like water, traveling or roaming. 旅游 combines 旅 (journey) + 游 (to roam/travel) to mean traveling around for fun or tourism.

examples.zh: 我最喜欢在假期去国外旅游。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ zuì xǐhuan zài jiàqī qù guówài lǚyóu.
examples.en: I like traveling abroad the most during holidays.

examples.zh: 很多人选择跟团旅游，因为比较省心。
examples.pinyin: Hěn duō rén xuǎnzé gēn tuán lǚyóu, yīnwèi bǐjiào shěngxīn.
examples.en: Many people choose to travel with tour groups because it’s more worry-free.

examples.zh: 如果有时间，我们一起去中国旅游吧。
examples.pinyin: Rúguǒ yǒu shíjiān, wǒmen yìqǐ qù Zhōngguó lǚyóu ba.
examples.en: If we have time, let’s travel to China together.

memoryStory: A traveler (旅) puts a little flag on their backpack and jumps into a river of glowing water (游). The water carries them past floating landmarks like the Eiffel Tower and the Great Wall. Everywhere they go, the flag waves wildly, shouting: “This is for FUN travel only—旅游!”
imagePrompt: A person with a backpack and small flag surfing on a glowing blue river that flows through the sky, passing futuristic holographic landmarks (Great Wall, Eiffel Tower) connected by neon network lines, in a sci‑fi cityscape at dusk, no text.
rawDictEntry: 旅遊 旅游 [lǔ: yóu] /trip/journey/tourism/travel/tour/to travel/

meaning: 卖 (mài) means to sell, to betray (figuratively ‘sell someone out’), to spare no effort in promoting something, or to show off/flaunt (as in ‘selling cuteness’ or ‘selling misery’ to gain sympathy).
components: 卖 is written as ⿱十买. Top: 十 (shí), literally “ten,” often suggesting quantity or completion. Bottom: 买 (mǎi), “to buy.” Putting “ten” over “buy” suggests handling many purchases—what a shopkeeper does: they buy in bulk in order to sell. Note: 买 (buy) + 十 (ten) → 卖 (sell).

examples.zh: 他在网上卖自己的手工艺品。
examples.pinyin: Tā zài wǎngshàng mài zìjǐ de shǒugōng yìpǐn.
examples.en: He sells his handmade crafts online.

examples.zh: 别为了钱出卖朋友的信任。
examples.pinyin: Bié wèi le qián chūmài péngyou de xìnrèn.
examples.en: Don’t betray your friends’ trust for money.

examples.zh: 她在直播里拼命卖货。
examples.pinyin: Tā zài zhíbō lǐ pīnmìng mài huò.
examples.en: She spares no effort selling products in her livestream.

memoryStory: A shopkeeper named “Maaii!” (mài, falling tone) buys ONE thing, then TEN more (十) and shouts dramatically, “I’ll SELL them ALL!” He’s so desperate he almost sells out his FRIENDS too—remember: 买 (buy) plus 十 (ten) becomes 卖 (sell).
imagePrompt: Futuristic street market at night, glowing neon stalls. A robot vendor stands behind a counter stacked with ten bright holographic items. Digital price tags float above, and data streams form a network overhead, emphasizing the act of selling goods in a sci‑fi marketplace.
rawDictEntry: 賣 卖 [mài] /to sell/to betray/to spare no effort/to show off or flaunt/

meaning: slow; not fast; to take one’s time; to delay or be delayed; sluggish (can describe speed, reaction, or tempo). Often used for moving or doing something slowly, or asking someone not to hurry.
components:
慢 is ⿰忄曼.
- 忄: the “heart” radical, related to feelings, attitude, or mental state.
- 曼: originally shows something long, extended, graceful or drawn-out. Together, a “drawn-out” (曼) feeling in the “heart” (忄) gives the idea of doing things slowly, unhurriedly.

examples.zh: 请慢一点说，我听不懂。
examples.pinyin: Qǐng màn yìdiǎn shuō, wǒ tīng bù dǒng.
examples.en: Please speak a bit more slowly, I can’t understand.

examples.zh: 他走得很慢，好像一点也不着急。
examples.pinyin: Tā zǒu de hěn màn, hǎoxiàng yìdiǎn yě bù zhāojí.
examples.en: He walks very slowly, as if he isn’t in a hurry at all.

examples.zh: 网络太慢了，视频一直在加载。
examples.pinyin: Wǎngluò tài màn le, shìpín yìzhí zài jiāzài.
examples.en: The internet is too slow; the video keeps loading.

memoryStory: Your HEART (忄) is watching a super long, stretched-out sci‑fi movie (曼) that never ends. Time feels painfully SLOW—your heart is like, “Màn… can this ever finish?” The drawn-out movie makes you remember màn (fourth tone down) means slow.
imagePrompt: A futuristic city street at night with glowing neon, but everything is frozen in ultra-slow motion: a hovering car barely moving, light trails stretched long, a person mid-step. Digital heart-shaped core on a chest glows, pulsing slowly, connected to a shimmering network grid in the sky.
rawDictEntry: 慢 慢 [màn] /slow/

meaning: 忙 (máng) means busy, occupied, in a hurry, or to rush. It describes having many things to do, being pressed for time, or acting hurriedly.
components: 忙 is ⿰忄亡. 忄 is the “heart” radical, related to feelings and mental states. 亡 means “to lose” or “to disappear.” Put together: when your heart feels like it’s ‘lost’ or disappearing, you’re overwhelmed and BUSY.

examples.zh: 我这几天很忙，没有时间休息。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ zhè jǐ tiān hěn máng, méiyǒu shíjiān xiūxi.
examples.en: I’ve been very busy these days and have no time to rest.

examples.zh: 你现在忙吗？我想跟你聊一会儿。
examples.pinyin: Nǐ xiànzài máng ma? Wǒ xiǎng gēn nǐ liáo yīhuìr.
examples.en: Are you busy now? I’d like to chat with you for a while.

examples.zh: 他忙着赶报告，一直没吃饭。
examples.pinyin: Tā mángzhe gǎn bàogào, yīzhí méi chīfàn.
examples.en: He’s busy rushing to finish the report and hasn’t eaten.

memoryStory: A tiny heart (忄) runs around an office so frantically it gets LOST (亡) under a pile of papers. The boss shouts, “MÁNG! MÁNG!” Every time work makes your heart feel lost, remember 忄 + 亡 = 忙 (máng), super busy.
imagePrompt: In a futuristic neon-lit office, a glowing red heart-shaped robot frantically dashes between holographic desks, buried under floating data sheets, while parts of it flicker and fade as if disappearing, all connected by bright digital networks in a sci‑fi city backdrop.
rawDictEntry: 忙 忙 [máng] /busy/hurriedly/to hurry/to rush/

meaning: 每 (měi) means “each” or “every,” indicating that something applies to all items or all times in a group (e.g., every day, each person, every time).
components: 每 is written as ⿱𠂉母. The top part 𠂉 looks like a small person or a hand reaching down. The bottom part 母 means “mother.” Put together, you can imagine a mother dealing with each and every child or item one by one, giving the sense of “each, every.”

examples.zh: 我每天六点起床。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ měi tiān liù diǎn qǐchuáng.
examples.en: I get up at six o’clock every day.

examples.zh: 每个人都有自己的梦想。

meaning: Younger sister; can also casually refer to a young woman or girl (often affectionate).
components: 妹 is ⿰女未: 女 (nǚ) means “woman, female”; 未 (wèi) means “not yet.” Together, 妹 suggests a female who is “not yet” grown up — a younger girl. 妹妹 is simply the doubling of 妹, emphasizing the idea of a younger sister or young girl.

examples.zh: 我有一個妹妹，她很喜歡畫畫。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ yǒu yí gè mèimei, tā hěn xǐhuan huàhuà.

examples.zh: 妹妹比我小三歲。

meaning: 门 (mén): door, gate, or entrance; also a measure word for school subjects and branches of learning; by extension a way or method, a family or household, a sect or school of thought, and in modern usage the suffix “-gate” for scandals.
components: 门 is both a standalone character and the ‘door’ radical. It originally depicts a pair of swinging doors in a doorway. The two side strokes are the doorposts, and the opening in the middle is the passage you go through. Its core idea is anything like a door, gate, or entry point.

examples.zh: 请关门，好冷。
examples.pinyin: Qǐng guān mén, hǎo lěng.
examples.en: Please close the door, it’s really cold.

examples.zh: 我今天有三门课。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ jīntiān yǒu sān mén kè.

examples.zh: 学习一门外语可以打开很多机会之门。
examples.pinyin: Xuéxí yī mén wàiyǔ kěyǐ dǎkāi hěn duō jīhuì zhī mén.
examples.en: Learning a foreign language can open many doors of opportunity.

meaning: 男人 means a man, a male adult person, or men in general. It refers to a human who is male, usually emphasizing adulthood rather than a boy.
components: 男 is composed of 田 (tián, “field”) over 力 (lì, “strength, power”), suggesting physical strength used to work the fields – traditionally associated with males. 人 (rén) means “person” or “human.” Together, 男人 literally combines “male/field-strength” + “person,” meaning “a male person, a man.”

examples.zh: 那个男人是我的老师。
examples.pinyin: Nà gè nánrén shì wǒ de lǎoshī.

examples.zh: 她觉得这个男人很幽默。

examples.zh: 这里的男人都很友好。
examples.pinyin: Zhèlǐ de nánrén dōu hěn yǒuhǎo.
examples.en: The men here are all very friendly.

meaning: You (polite, respectful form), used to address someone formally or to show respect, similar to saying “Sir/Madam” or using a formal ‘you’ in other languages.
components: 您 is written as ⿱你心: the top part 你 (nǐ, “you”) plus the bottom part 心 (xīn, “heart”). Put together, it suggests “you + heart” — speaking to someone with your heart, showing extra respect and politeness.

examples.zh: 您好，请问您贵姓？
examples.pinyin: Nín hǎo, qǐngwèn nín guì xìng?
examples.en: Hello, may I ask your honorable surname?

examples.zh: 谢谢您今天帮了我这么多忙。

examples.en: Thank you for helping me so much today.

examples.zh: 老师，您可以再说一遍吗？
examples.pinyin: Lǎoshī, nín kěyǐ zài shuō yí biàn ma?
examples.en: Teacher, could you say it one more time?

meaning: Cow’s milk; the white liquid produced by cows that humans commonly drink or use in cooking. Can also refer generally to milk from cows as a product (a glass, a bottle, etc.).
components:
牛奶 is made of two characters:
- 牛 (niú): means “cow” or “ox.” The character itself looks a bit like horns and a head of a cow.
- 奶 (nǎi): means “milk,” “breast,” or sometimes “grandma” (as in 奶奶). It is written as ⿰女乃:
  - 女 (nǚ): “woman, female,” suggesting the source of milk.
  - 乃 (nǎi): an old character meaning “thus/then,” here mainly for sound, giving the nǎi pronunciation.
Together, 牛 (cow) + 奶 (milk) literally means “cow milk.”

examples.zh: 我每天早上喝一杯牛奶。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ měi tiān zǎo shang hē yì bēi niú nǎi.
examples.en: I drink a glass of milk every morning.

examples.zh: 他对牛奶过敏，所以只喝豆浆。
examples.pinyin: Tā duì niú nǎi guòmǐn, suǒyǐ zhǐ hē dòujiāng.
examples.en: He is allergic to milk, so he only drinks soy milk.

examples.zh: 请给孩子多准备一些牛奶。
examples.pinyin: Qǐng gěi háizi duō zhǔnbèi yìxiē niú nǎi.
examples.en: Please prepare some extra milk for the child.

memoryStory: A stylish COW (牛 niú) opens a café. Instead of coffee, she proudly serves only her own MILK (奶 nǎi). Customers shout “niú!” (awesome!) and “nǎi!” (milk!) as the cow barista sprays white milk everywhere like a foam party. Cow + milk = 牛奶, niú nǎi.

rawDictEntry: 牛奶 牛奶 [niú nǎi] /cow's milk/CL:瓶[píng],杯[bēi]/

meaning: 女人 means a woman, an adult female person. In context it can also refer to one’s wife or female partner, depending on who is speaking and the situation.
components: 女 (nǚ) means “woman, female.” 人 (rén) means “person, human.” Put together, 女 + 人 literally forms “female person,” which is exactly the idea of a woman or, in some contexts, one’s wife.

examples.zh: 那个女人是我的老师。
examples.pinyin: Nà gè nǚrén shì wǒ de lǎoshī.
examples.en: That woman is my teacher.

examples.zh: 他常常夸自己的女人很聪明。
examples.pinyin: Tā chángcháng kuā zìjǐ de nǚrén hěn cōngmíng.

examples.pinyin: Zhège gōngsī yǒu hěn duō yōuxiù de nǚrén.
examples.en: There are many outstanding women in this company.

imagePrompt: In a neon-lit futuristic city, a glowing female figure (clear curves, long hair) stands confidently among simple stick-figure humans. Digital networks and light grids connect around her, highlighting her as the central ‘female person.’ No text, clean sci‑fi style.

meaning: 旁边 means “the side” or “the place next to something,” describing a location that is adjacent or immediately nearby.
components:
旁: A complex top part (亠, 丷, 冖) over 方. 亠 often hints at a roof or top, 冖 is a cover, and 方 suggests “direction/side.” Together you can imagine a covered area marking a particular side or direction.
边: 辶 is the “walking/movement” radical, suggesting paths or edges; 力 means “strength, force.” Picture someone using strength to walk along the outer edge or border of something. Combined, 旁边 is the side/place you walk along next to something.

examples.zh: 他就坐在我旁边。
examples.pinyin: Tā jiù zuò zài wǒ pángbiān.
examples.en: He is sitting right next to me.

examples.zh: 书店旁边有一家咖啡馆。
examples.pinyin: Shūdiàn pángbiān yǒu yì jiā kāfēiguǎn.
examples.en: There is a café next to the bookstore.

examples.zh: 请把手机放在电脑旁边。
examples.pinyin: Qǐng bǎ shǒujī fàng zài diànnǎo pángbiān.
examples.en: Please put your phone next to the computer.

memoryStory: Imagine a giant glowing compass 方 under a roof (亠, 冖) labeled “VIP side only.” A muscular guard 力 is pacing along the path 辶 right next to it. He shouts: “Only stand at the SIDE NEXT TO me—just at my 旁边!” The bright compass marks the side; the walking guard marks the edge.
imagePrompt: Futuristic city street at night: a glowing robot stands beside a sleek hovering car, clearly positioned at its side. Neon pathways trace lines on the ground showing the car’s edge and the robot right next to it. Holographic buildings and network-like light patterns in the sky.
rawDictEntry: 旁邊 旁边 [páng biān] /side; adjacent place/

meaning: 跑步 means to run or to jog, usually as a form of exercise or movement. In a military context, it can also mean to march at the double (moving at a running pace instead of walking).
components:
跑步 is made of two characters: 跑 and 步。
- 跑: ⿰𧾷包
  - The left side 𧾷 is the “foot/leg” radical, related to movement and walking/running.
  - The right side 包 (bāo) means “to wrap, bag” and here mainly gives the sound (pǎo is phonetically related).
  Together, a “foot” radical plus a sound component suggests an action with the feet → running.

- 步: ⿱止𣥂
  - The top part 止 (zhǐ) means “to stop,” but it is also related historically to a foot or step.
  - The bottom part 𣥂 is an ancient component related to steps/foot movement.
  Combined, 步 means “step” or “to walk.”

So 跑步 literally combines “run” (跑) + “steps” (步) → the action of running/jogging.

examples.zh: 我每天早上去公园跑步。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ měitiān zǎoshang qù gōngyuán pǎobù.
examples.en: I go to the park to run every morning.

examples.zh: 医生建议他多跑步，注意健康。
examples.pinyin: Yīshēng jiànyì tā duō pǎobù, zhùyì jiànkāng.
examples.en: The doctor suggested that he run more and pay attention to his health.

examples.zh: 新兵在操场上跑步训练。
examples.pinyin: Xīnbīng zài cāochǎng shàng pǎobù xùnliàn.
examples.en: The new recruits are doing running drills on the training field.

memoryStory: Imagine a tiny delivery guy inside a big 包 (bag), with only his legs (𧾷) sticking out, forced to 跑 wildly to deliver packages faster. Each 步 (step) he takes lights up the ground like a video game. You hear him panting “pǎo-bù, pǎo-bù” as he runs nonstop.
imagePrompt: A person jogging on a glowing futuristic track at night, each footstep lighting up in neon. Cyberpunk city skyline in the background with network-like lines tracing their running path through the air. No text, clear focus on running motion and steps.
rawDictEntry: 跑步 跑步 [pǎo bù] /to run/to jog/(military) to march at the double/

meaning: 便宜 most commonly (pián yi) means “cheap; inexpensive,” often with a neutral or positive tone about low price. It can also mean “to give someone an undeserved advantage” or “to let someone off lightly.” The pronunciation (biàn yí) is a rarer reading meaning “convenient, expedient.”
components:
便: ⿰亻(standing person) + 更(change, more). Picture a person changing or making things easier or more convenient.
宜: ⿱宀(roof, house) + 且(a block, something placed). Under a roof, things are properly arranged, suitable and appropriate.
Together, 便宜 suggests a person making things suitably arranged and easy—prices or conditions become “convenient,” then extended to “cheap, a bargain, an easy advantage.”

examples.zh: 这家店的衣服很便宜，而且质量不错。
examples.pinyin: Zhè jiā diàn de yīfu hěn pián yi, érqiě zhìliàng bùcuò.
examples.en: The clothes in this shop are very cheap, and the quality is pretty good.

examples.zh: 机票太贵了，我想再等等，看有没有更便宜的。
examples.pinyin: Jīpiào tài guì le, wǒ xiǎng zài děng děng, kàn yǒu méiyǒu gèng pián yi de.
examples.en: The plane tickets are too expensive. I want to wait and see if there are any cheaper ones.

examples.zh: 别让他白占便宜，该付的钱还是得付。
examples.pinyin: Bié ràng tā bái zhàn pián yi, gāi fù de qián hái shì děi fù.
examples.en: Don’t let him take advantage for free; the money that should be paid still has to be paid.

memoryStory: Under a glowing sci‑fi roof (宜), a person (亻) is hacking prices, changing them lower and lower (更). Shoppers cheer at the “convenient” deal and feel they’re getting an easy advantage. Remember: pián yi = shockingly cheap, almost too convenient a bargain.
imagePrompt: Futuristic street market at night under a glowing digital roof; a human-shaped vendor taps a holographic panel, prices dropping visibly on floating items. Crowds rush to grab ultra-cheap goods, neon colors and network-like light patterns connecting stalls.
rawDictEntry: 便宜 便宜 [biàn yí] /convenient/

meaning: 票 (piào): ticket; ballot; banknote; a person held for ransom; an amateur performance of Chinese opera; also a classifier for groups, batches, or business transactions.
components: 票 is written as ⿱覀示. The top part 覀 (yà) is a variant related to a cover or something spread out, often seen in characters connected to things laid out or displayed. The lower part 示 (shì) is the “altar” or “spirit” component, originally an offering table, and often appears in characters about signs, marks, or formal items. Together you can imagine a formal marked slip laid out on an altar-like table — a special piece of paper, like a ticket, ballot, or banknote.

examples.zh: 我已经买好电影票了。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ yǐjīng mǎi hǎo diànyǐng piào le.
examples.en: I’ve already bought the movie tickets.

examples.zh: 请把选票投进那个箱子里。
examples.pinyin: Qǐng bǎ xuǎnpiào tóu jìn nàge xiāngzi lǐ.
examples.en: Please cast your ballot into that box.

examples.zh: 他拿着一大叠钱票走进了银行。
examples.pinyin: Tā názhe yī dà dié qiánpiào zǒu jìnle yínháng.
examples.en: He walked into the bank holding a big stack of banknotes.

memoryStory: On a temple-like altar (示), a ticket robot is laying out (覀) shiny movie tickets, ballots, and money. To get in, you must shout “piào!” in a high, sharp second tone, and the robot showers you with tickets and cash like a crazy raffle.
imagePrompt: Futuristic ticket booth on a glowing altar table, holographic tickets, ballots, and banknotes floating above it, a small robot handing out luminous slips to people in a neon-lit sci‑fi city, with network-like light lines connecting each ticket to different destinations.
rawDictEntry: 票 票 [piào] /ticket/ballot/banknote/CL:張|张[zhāng]/person held for ransom/amateur performance of Chinese opera/classifier for groups, batches, business transactions/

meaning: Wife; one’s female marital partner. In classical or literary usage, 妻子 can also mean ‘wife and children’ as a family unit, but in modern everyday Chinese it most commonly just means ‘wife’.
components:
妻: Top is a complex shape ⿱⿻十⿻コ一 over 女 (woman). Historically it depicts a woman involved in formal union or household duties, giving the meaning of “wife.”
子: A pictograph of a child with a big head and small body, meaning “child, son.”
Together, 妻子 originally suggested “wife and child(ren),” the core family members. In modern usage, the compound mainly refers to the wife herself.

examples.zh: 他介绍妻子给我们认识。
examples.pinyin: Tā jièshào qīzi gěi wǒmen rènshi.
examples.en: He introduced his wife to us.

examples.zh: 我妻子是老师，经常加班。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ qīzi shì lǎoshī, jīngcháng jiābān.
examples.en: My wife is a teacher and often works overtime.

examples.zh: 他为了妻子和孩子非常努力工作。
examples.pinyin: Tā wèile qīzi hé háizi fēicháng nǔlì gōngzuò.
examples.en: He works very hard for his wife and children.

memoryStory: On a glowing futuristic wedding stage, a WOMAN (女) in a cyber-dress signs a digital cross (十) contract to become a WIFE (妻). Right away, a tiny hologram CHILD (子) pops out, yelling “qīzi, qīzi!”—they’re now a sci‑fi wife-and-child family unit.
imagePrompt: Futuristic city apartment: a woman in a sleek cyberpunk wedding dress holds hands with a small glowing child hologram. Around them, neon network lines form a heart-shaped circuit, suggesting a family unit. No text, clean background, soft sci‑fi glow and clear silhouettes.
rawDictEntry: 妻子 妻子 [qī zǐ] /wife and children/

meaning: 起床 means “to get out of bed; to get up.” It refers specifically to the action of leaving your bed, usually in the morning or after sleeping, not just waking up mentally.
components:
起: ⿺走巳 — The left part 走 means “to walk, to move,” suggesting movement. The right part 巳 is a pictograph once related to a curled shape (and also the Chinese zodiac snake), used here mainly for sound.
床: ⿸广木 — The top-left 广 shows a shelter or building, like a simple house or room. The bottom 木 means “wood.” Together they suggest a wooden object inside a shelter: a wooden bed or platform.

examples.zh: 我每天六点起床。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ měi tiān liù diǎn qǐchuáng.
examples.en: I get up at six o’clock every day.

examples.zh: 起床以后，我先喝一杯水。
examples.pinyin: Qǐchuáng yǐhòu, wǒ xiān hē yì bēi shuǐ.
examples.en: After getting up, I first drink a glass of water.

examples.zh: 今天太累了，我不想起床。
examples.pinyin: Jīntiān tài lèi le, wǒ bù xiǎng qǐchuáng.
examples.en: I’m so tired today that I don’t want to get out of bed.

memoryStory: A lazy snake (巳) is lying in a wooden bed (木) under a roof (广). An alarm rings and the floor starts to walk away (走)! To avoid being carried off, the snake must quickly “walk” out of bed—qǐchuáng—getting up before the bed escapes.
imagePrompt: Futuristic bedroom with a sleek wooden bed under a minimal roof-like structure, glowing alarm hovering above. A groggy person is stepping out of bed as the floor forms glowing circuit paths, like walking networks, in a sci‑fi neon style. No text.
rawDictEntry: 起床 起床 [qǐ chuáng] /to get out of bed; to get up/

meaning: “千” means “thousand,” indicating the number 1,000 or a very large quantity. It can also appear in words like 秋千 (qiūqiān, swing), where it no longer keeps the numeric meaning but is part of a fixed compound.
components: “千” is written as ⿱丿十: the top stroke 丿 is a slanting stroke, and 十 means “ten.” You can imagine stacking or extending “ten” with an extra stroke above it, suggesting many tens piled up, becoming a large number: one thousand.

examples.zh: 这里有一千个人。
examples.pinyin: Zhèlǐ yǒu yī qiān gè rén.
examples.en: There are one thousand people here.

examples.zh: 他已经写了几千个汉字。
examples.pinyin: Tā yǐjīng xiě le jǐ qiān gè Hànzì.
examples.en: He has already written several thousand Chinese characters.

examples.zh: 千里之行，始于足下。
examples.pinyin: Qiān lǐ zhī xíng, shǐ yú zú xià.
examples.en: A journey of a thousand miles begins with a single step.

memoryStory: Imagine a giant number “10” (十) standing on a stage. A wild slanted stroke (丿) zips in like a lightning bolt, hits the 10, and it instantly clones itself into a crowd of 1,000 tiny tens chanting “qiān! qiān!” in perfect high-level tone.
imagePrompt: Futuristic city plaza with a glowing holographic number 1000 towering over tiny people, neon-blue light beams forming networks in the sky, each beam splitting from a central vertical bar like 十 with an extra slanted stroke on top, sci‑fi style, no text.
rawDictEntry: 千 千 [qiān] /thousand/

meaning: 晴 means clear or fine weather, usually describing a day with sunshine and no rain or clouds. It can also be used in contrast with 阴 (overcast) or 雨 (rainy) to talk about good, bright weather.
components: 晴 is ⿰日青. On the left, 日 means “sun.” On the right, 青 originally shows a vivid blue-green color and can suggest brightness or clarity. Together, the bright sun (日) plus clear blue sky (青) gives the idea of a sunny, clear day: 晴.

examples.zh: 今天是晴天，我们去公园吧。
examples.pinyin: Jīntiān shì qíngtiān, wǒmen qù gōngyuán ba.
examples.en: Today is a sunny day, let’s go to the park.

examples.zh: 下了几天雨，终于放晴了。
examples.pinyin: Xià le jǐ tiān yǔ, zhōngyú fàng qíng le.
examples.en: It rained for several days, and finally it cleared up.

examples.zh: 天气预报说明天转晴。
examples.pinyin: Tiānqì yùbào shuō míngtiān zhuǎn qíng.
examples.en: The weather forecast says it will turn sunny tomorrow.

memoryStory: Imagine the sun 日 applying blue-green makeup 青 to the sky like a painter. It shouts in a high, rising tone “qíng!” and all the clouds run away in fear, leaving a perfectly clear, sunny day for you to go outside.
imagePrompt: A futuristic city under a perfectly clear blue sky, bright sun shining. Transparent holographic weather icons float in the air showing a glowing sun symbol. Sleek towers connected by light networks, no clouds, everything bathed in warm, clear sunlight.

meaning: 去年 means “last year,” referring to the entire calendar year directly before the current one.
components: 去: ⿱土厶 — 上面是“土” (earth, ground)，下面是“厶” (private, oneself)。可以联想为：把自己从这片土地上“离开、去往”别处。年: 表示“年、岁数、收成的一年”。合在一起，去年就是已经“离开我们”的那一年——刚刚过去的那一年。

examples.zh: 去年我第一次去中国旅游。
examples.pinyin: Qùnián wǒ dì-yī cì qù Zhōngguó lǚyóu.
examples.en: Last year I went to China for the first time.

examples.zh: 去年这里的房价涨得很快。
examples.pinyin: Qùnián zhèlǐ de fángjià zhǎng de hěn kuài.
examples.en: Last year, housing prices here rose very quickly.

examples.zh: 比起前年，去年我的汉语进步很多。
examples.pinyin: Bǐqǐ qiánnián, qùnián wǒ de Hànyǔ jìnbù hěn duō.
examples.en: Compared with the year before last, my Chinese improved a lot last year.

meaning: 让 (ràng) means to yield, to give way, to allow or permit, to let someone do something, to have someone do something, or to make someone feel a certain way. It can also mark the agent in a passive sentence, similar to 被 (bèi).
components: 让 is ⿰讠上. The left side 讠is the speech/words radical, related to talking and communication. The right side 上 means “up” or “above.” Put together, it suggests using words to ‘raise’ someone else up, to let them go first or to allow something to happen—hence the ideas of yielding, letting, and making.

examples.pinyin: Qǐng ràng tā xiān shuō.
examples.en: Please let him speak first.

examples.zh: 这件事让我很感动。
examples.pinyin: Zhè jiàn shì ràng wǒ hěn gǎndòng.
examples.en: This matter really moved me (made me feel very touched).

examples.zh: 我被他让到了前面。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ bèi tā ràng dào le qiánmiàn.
examples.en: I was given way by him and moved to the front.

meaning: 上班 means to go to work, to be on duty, to start working, or to be at one’s job/office. It describes the action or state of working, especially in a regular job or at a workplace.
components:
上: The character looks like a line with something rising above it, meaning “up, above, to go up.” Here it suggests starting or going upward toward a place or state.
班: Composed of repeating 王 (originally a jade piece or king). The repetition suggests a group or division. 班 came to mean a class, team, or shift of people. In 上班, it’s the work shift or work unit you go to.
Together: 上 (go up/start) + 班 (work shift/group) = to go up to your shift, i.e., to go to work or be on duty.

examples.zh: 我每天早上九点上班。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ měitiān zǎoshang jiǔ diǎn shàngbān.
examples.en: I go to work at nine o’clock every morning.

examples.zh: 今天是周末，不用上班。
examples.pinyin: Jīntiān shì zhōumò, búyòng shàngbān.
examples.en: Today is the weekend; I don’t need to go to work.

examples.zh: 她已经上班了，一会儿再给你回电话。
examples.pinyin: Tā yǐjīng shàngbān le, yīhuìr zài gěi nǐ huí diànhuà.
examples.en: She’s already at work; she’ll call you back later.

meaning: 身体 means the body or one’s physical health. It can refer to the whole human body, a person’s physical condition, or sometimes the physical form of a living being.
components:
身: a pictograph of a human body or torso, representing the whole body.
体: ⿰亻本 — the left side 亻 is the “person” radical, indicating it’s about a human; 本 shows a tree with a mark at the root, meaning “root/origin.” Together, 体 suggests the basic form or structure of a person — the body.

examples.pinyin: Nǐ de shēntǐ zěnme yàng?
examples.en: How is your health? / How is your body doing?

examples.en: Exercising more is very good for the body.

examples.zh: 他生病了，身体很虚弱。
examples.pinyin: Tā shēngbìng le, shēntǐ hěn xūruò.
examples.en: He is sick, and his body is very weak.

meaning: 生病 means to become ill, to get sick, or to fall ill. It describes the state of a person (or sometimes an animal) when their body is not healthy due to disease, infection, or other health problems.
components:
生: Originally shows a sprout growing out of the ground, meaning “to give birth,” “to grow,” or “life.” Here it carries the idea of something starting or arising.
病: The radical 疒 on the left is the “sickness” or “illness” radical, depicting a person lying in bed. 丙 on the right is the phonetic part, giving the pronunciation clue (bǐng → bìng). Together, 病 means “illness.”
生 + 病: literally “to generate illness” → to become sick, to fall ill.

examples.zh: 他昨天受了凉，今天生病了。
examples.pinyin: Tā zuótiān shòu le liáng, jīntiān shēngbìng le.
examples.en: He caught a chill yesterday and got sick today.

examples.zh: 如果你生病了，一定要去看医生。
examples.pinyin: Rúguǒ nǐ shēngbìng le, yídìng yào qù kàn yīshēng.
examples.en: If you get sick, you must go see a doctor.

examples.zh: 最近天气变化很大，很多人都生病了。
examples.pinyin: Zuìjìn tiānqì biànhuà hěn dà, hěn duō rén dōu shēngbìng le.
examples.en: The weather has changed a lot recently; many people have gotten sick.

meaning: Birthday; the anniversary of a person’s birth, usually celebrated once a year, often with parties, cakes, gifts, and well-wishes.
components: 生 (shēng): means “to be born,” “life,” or “to grow.” It suggests the idea of coming into existence. 日 (rì): means “sun” or “day.” Together, 生日 literally means “birth-day,” the day marking one’s birth.

examples.zh: 今天是我的生日。
examples.pinyin: Jīntiān shì wǒ de shēngrì.
examples.en: Today is my birthday.

meaning: 时间 means the concept of time in general (like past, present, future), a period or duration of time, or a specific point in time (when something happens).
components: “时” is ⿰日寸: 日 (sun, day) + 寸 (a small unit, hand/measurement) — think of measuring the sun’s movement to tell time. “间” is ⿵门日: 门 (door) surrounding 日 (sun) — a door with the sun shining through, like a gap or interval. Together, 时间 is the measured intervals of the sun passing through our days — time.

examples.zh: 你现在有时间吗？
examples.pinyin: Nǐ xiànzài yǒu shíjiān ma?
examples.en: Do you have time right now?

examples.zh: 我每天花很多时间学习中文。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ měitiān huā hěn duō shíjiān xuéxí Zhōngwén.
examples.en: I spend a lot of time every day studying Chinese.

examples.zh: 时间过得太快了！
examples.pinyin: Shíjiān guò de tài kuài le!
examples.en: Time passes too quickly!

imagePrompt: A giant futuristic clock made of glowing sun-discs shining through a doorway-shaped frame, floating in space. Doors open and close, letting beams of sunlight form a glowing timeline network in the air, with tiny figures trying to measure the light with rulers.

meaning: 事情 means a matter, affair, event, or thing that happens or needs to be dealt with. It can refer to business, issues, tasks, or situations in daily life, work, or relationships.
components:
事: A pictograph originally related to official duties or tasks—think of formal business or affairs that must be handled.
情: ⿰忄(heart radical) + 青(qīng, blue/green, clear). 忄 suggests feelings or the heart; 青 suggests clarity or a situation. Together, 情 often relates to feelings or the emotional ‘state’ of a situation.
Combined, 事情 is the ‘affair/matter’ (事) plus the emotional/situational aspect (情): the concrete thing that’s going on, the matter at hand.

examples.zh: 你有什么事情要跟我说吗？
examples.pinyin: Nǐ yǒu shénme shìqing yào gēn wǒ shuō ma?
examples.en: Do you have something you want to talk to me about?

examples.zh: 最近公司有很多事情要处理。
examples.pinyin: Zuìjìn gōngsī yǒu hěn duō shìqing yào chǔlǐ.
examples.en: Recently the company has a lot of matters to deal with.

examples.zh: 这件事情先别急，我们慢慢想办法。
examples.pinyin: Zhè jiàn shìqing xiān bié jí, wǒmen mànman xiǎng bànfǎ.
examples.en: Don’t rush this matter; let’s slowly think of a solution.

memoryStory: An overworked office worker (事) opens his heart (忄) to complain about the endless ‘blue’ (青) folders on his desk. Each blue folder is a different ‘matter’ he must handle. All his heart and energy go into these 事情 piling up.

meaning: A wristwatch; a small timekeeping device worn on the wrist to tell the time.
components:
手表 = 手 + 表
- 手 (shǒu): means “hand.” It also suggests something done or worn with the hand.
- 表 (biǎo): originally a character related to an outer surface or something that shows on the outside; in modern use it can mean a meter, gauge, or watch that ‘displays’ information.
Together, 手 (hand) + 表 (display/gauge) = a device on the hand that displays time: a wristwatch.

examples.pinyin: Tā de shǒubiǎo měitiān dū huì zìdòng duì shíjiān.

examples.zh: 这块手表虽然很旧，但对我很有意义。

examples.en: Although this wristwatch is very old, it’s very meaningful to me.

meaning: Cell phone; mobile phone – a portable telephone you carry with you, used for calling, texting, internet, apps, etc.
components: 手 (shǒu) means “hand” – things you hold or do with your hand. 机 (jī) is ⿰木几: 木 (wood) + 几 (table/stand/ small device-like shape). 机 often appears in words for machines/devices. Together, 手机 is literally a “hand machine,” a device you hold in your hand.

meaning: 送 (sòng): to send; to deliver; to transmit; to give as a present; to see someone off; to accompany someone on their way.
components: 送 is ⿺辶关. 辶 is the “walking / movement” radical, showing motion or a journey. 关 (guān) means “to close; a checkpoint; a pass.” Together, imagine someone moving (辶) toward a checkpoint (关) to hand something over or accompany someone on their way—sending, delivering, seeing off.

meaning: 所以 means “therefore, so, as a result.” It links a reason to its result, like “so” or “therefore” in English. Often used after stating a cause to introduce the conclusion or consequence.
components: 所 (suǒ): from ⿰戶(door/household) + 斤(axe); originally a place where an axe is used → by extension, a place, that which. 以 (yǐ): a standalone character meaning “to use, by means of, in order to.” Together, 所以 literally hints at “that by which (something happens)” → the reason, the cause → therefore, so.

examples.zh: 他生病了，所以今天不来上课。
examples.pinyin: Tā shēngbìng le, suǒyǐ jīntiān bù lái shàngkè.
examples.en: He is sick, so he won’t come to class today.

examples.zh: 我昨天太累了，所以很早就睡了。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ zuótiān tài lèi le, suǒyǐ hěn zǎo jiù shuì le.
examples.en: I was too tired yesterday, so I went to bed very early.

examples.zh: 天气很好，所以我们决定去公园。
examples.pinyin: Tiānqì hěn hǎo, suǒyǐ wǒmen juédìng qù gōngyuán.
examples.en: The weather is very good, so we decided to go to the park.

memoryStory: A scientist stands at a big DOOR (戶) holding an AXE (斤), trying to figure out why his robot broke. He shouts, “By what MEANS (以) did this explode?!” The robot calmly replies, “You hit me with an axe, SO… (所以) I exploded.” Cause → therefore → result.
imagePrompt: Futuristic lab corridor with a glowing door and a robotic axe stuck in a broken robot. Neon lines connect the axe to a bright arrow pointing to the shattered robot, visually showing cause and result. Sci‑fi holographic networks glow around them.
rawDictEntry: 所以 所以 [suǒ yǐ] /therefore/as a result/so/the reason why/

meaning: A third-person pronoun meaning “it,” usually for things, animals, or abstract ideas (not people).
components: 它 is written as ⿱宀匕: 宀 is the “roof” component, suggesting a house or something covered; 匕 originally looks like a small spoon or a bent object. Together they form the character used as the pronoun “it,” referring to non-human things or animals.

meaning: 踢 (tī) means to kick with the foot, or by extension to play ball games that mainly use the feet (like soccer). In slang, it can also refer to a ‘butch’ or more masculine-presenting partner in a lesbian relationship.
components: 踢 is ⿰𧾷易. The left side 𧾷 is the “foot” component (related to 走之, movement and legs), hinting at actions done with the feet. The right side 易 (easy, to change) acts as a phonetic part and suggests motion or change—together, a foot making a strong, changing impact: a kick.

examples.en: She plays as a forward on the team, and she’s really fast.

meaning: 题 (tí) means a topic, problem, or question, especially an exam question or exercise. It can also mean a subject for discussion, a title or heading, or to inscribe/write a title or short note on something.
components: 题 is written as ⿺是页. The right side 页 is the phonetic component, suggesting the sound (tí). The left side 是 originally shows a sun over a footprint and often relates to concepts of being or correctness. Together, you can imagine a ‘correct thing’ written on a ‘page’—a proper question, title, or topic on paper.

examples.zh: 这道题很难，我不会做。
examples.pinyin: Zhè dào tí hěn nán, wǒ bú huì zuò.

examples.zh: 今天作文的题目是什么？

meaning: 跳舞 means “to dance” — to move your body rhythmically, usually to music, for fun, performance, or exercise.
components: 跳: ⿰𧾷兆. 左边“𧾷”是“足”之类的走路、脚步偏旁，表示和脚、动作有关；右边“兆”作声旁，提示读音接近“tiào”。整体像“脚步+兆头/预兆”，好像脚一动，就预兆要开始跳起来。舞: ⿱⿳𠂉卌一舛。上面复杂的部分像人举着双手，下面“舛”像两只交错的脚，整个字就像一个人手舞足蹈地跳舞。合在一起，跳舞=用脚跳动、手脚并用地舞动。

examples.zh: 他们每个周末都去酒吧跳舞。
examples.pinyin: Tāmen měi ge zhōumò dōu qù jiǔbā tiàowǔ.
examples.en: They go to the bar to dance every weekend.

examples.zh: 我不会跳舞，但是我很想学。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ bú huì tiàowǔ, dànshì wǒ hěn xiǎng xué.
examples.en: I can’t dance, but I really want to learn.

examples.zh: 音乐一响，大家就站起来跳舞了。
examples.pinyin: Yīnyuè yī xiǎng, dàjiā jiù zhàn qǐlái tiàowǔ le.
examples.en: As soon as the music started, everyone stood up and began to dance.

memoryStory: 一个外星DJ在月球上放歌，地面像“足”一样长满小脚丫。音乐一响，这些脚预兆般(兆)全都弹跳起来，拼成一个大大的“舞”字：上面是疯狂挥舞的手，下面是交错乱踩的脚——所有人都在大跳舞(tiào wǔ)！

meaning: outside; outer; external; foreign; abroad; in addition; other than; referring to things or people not belonging to the inside, core, or one’s own group/country.
components: 外 is ⿰夕卜: on the left 夕 (xī) means “evening, dusk,” and on the right 卜 (bǔ) originally means “to divine, to predict.” One way to feel it: in the evening, people go *outside* and even do fortune-telling *outdoors*, beyond the house. Together they hint at what is beyond the inside — the outside, the external.

examples.zh: 我在外面等你。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ zài wàimiàn děng nǐ.

examples.zh: 他在国外工作。

examples.zh: 这件事和我无关，是外人的事。
examples.pinyin: Zhè jiàn shì hé wǒ wúguān, shì wàirén de shì.
examples.en: This matter has nothing to do with me; it’s an outsider’s business.

memoryStory: At night (夕), a fortune-teller (卜) sets up a booth just *outside* the city gate. Everyone must go *out* to see him. When he shouts “Come outside!” his voice rises sharply on wài (fourth tone), like a sudden command pulling you out the door.

A lone figure stands beyond the dome’s boundary, with holographic fortune-telling symbols floating in the air, neon networks of light tracing the dome’s outer surface, emphasizing being outside the protected interior.

meaning: to finish; to be over; to be done; whole; complete; entire; indicating that something has reached its end or is in a finished, intact state.
components: 完 is ⿱宀元: 宀 is the “roof” radical, suggesting a house or something covered. 元 means “origin, first, primary” and also suggests something basic or whole. Together, under one roof (宀) everything from the beginning (元) is done and complete → 完, to finish, complete.

examples.zh: 作业还没完，你先别玩手机。
examples.pinyin: Zuòyè hái méi wán, nǐ xiān bié wán shǒujī.

examples.zh: 电影完了以后，我们去吃饭吧。
examples.pinyin: Diànyǐng wán le yǐhòu, wǒmen qù chīfàn ba.
examples.en: After the movie is over, let’s go eat.

examples.zh: 事情总算圆满完成了，一切都完美结束。
examples.pinyin: Shìqing zǒngsuàn yuánmǎn wánchéng le, yīqiè dōu wánměi jiéshù.
examples.en: The matter is finally completed satisfactorily; everything ended perfectly.

meaning: 玩 (wán) means to play, to have fun, to amuse oneself, to toy with or trifle with something, or to keep something for entertainment (like a curio or collectible). In Taiwan it can also be pronounced wàn in certain contexts, especially for antiques or curios.
components:
玩 is ⿰王 + 元.
- 王 (wáng): literally “king; jade; ruler.” As a side component here, it suggests something precious or important.
- 元 (yuán): “beginning; first; primary; basic.”
Put together: from the ‘king’ (王) and the ‘beginning’ (元) comes the basic, precious human activity—having fun and playing. It hints that play is a fundamental, valuable part of life.

examples.zh: 小孩子在公园里玩得很开心。
examples.pinyin: Xiǎo háizi zài gōngyuán lǐ wán de hěn kāixīn.
examples.en: The children are playing very happily in the park.

examples.zh: 周末你喜欢玩什么？
examples.pinyin: Zhōumò nǐ xǐhuan wán shénme?
examples.en: What do you like to do for fun on weekends?

examples.zh: 别拿别人的感情开玩笑，更不要玩弄别人。
examples.pinyin: Bié ná biérén de gǎnqíng kāi wánxiào, gèng búyào wánnòng biérén.
examples.en: Don’t make jokes about other people’s feelings, and definitely don’t toy with them.

memoryStory: A bored king (王 wáng) at the very beginning of time (元 yuán) declares: “From now on, everyone must PLAY!” He slams his jade scepter and the world turns into a giant playground. The first sound of universal fun echoes: “wán! wán! wán!”

meaning: Evening; nighttime period after sunset and before late night. Used to talk about activities or time that happen in the evening, like eating dinner, going out, or relaxing after the day.
components: 晚: ⿰日免 — Left 日 (sun, day) + right 免 (to avoid/escape). Think of the sun trying to escape and hide, so it becomes late in the day. 上: ⿱⺊一 — Top ⺊ (upward mark) over 一 (line), meaning “above, on, up.” Together, 晚上 literally suggests the time when the day is late and things are ‘up/on’ in the evening sky.

examples.zh: 我晚上七点吃晚饭。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ wǎnshang qī diǎn chī wǎnfàn.
examples.en: I eat dinner at seven in the evening.

examples.zh: 晚上出去散步很舒服。
examples.pinyin: Wǎnshang chūqù sànbù hěn shūfu.
examples.en: Going out for a walk in the evening is very comfortable.

examples.pinyin: Tā wǎnshang chángcháng jiābān dào hěn wǎn.
examples.en: He often works overtime until very late at night.

memoryStory: Imagine the SUN (日) trying to ESCAPE (免) from work, sneaking away as it gets late: that’s 晚. As it runs upward onto the NIGHT SKY (上 = up), the whole world clocks out together—welcome to 晚上, the evening escape time.

meaning: 为 has two main readings. wéi: to be, to become, to act as, to serve as, to do; also used in passive patterns (被…所为). wèi: for, for the sake of, because of, on behalf of, to (do something for someone or some goal).
components: 为 is a simplified character written as a single unit (also the simplified form of 為). Historically it depicts a hand doing something, so you can link it to action and purpose. Think: a compact shape showing someone ‘doing’ something for a reason.

examples.zh: 他为老师，也为朋友。
examples.pinyin: Tā wéi lǎoshī, yě wèi péngyǒu.
examples.en: He is a teacher, and also does things for his friends.

examples.zh: 我为你做这件事。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ wèi nǐ zuò zhè jiàn shì.
examples.en: I do this for you.

examples.zh: 不要只为自己，要为大家着想。
examples.pinyin: Búyào zhǐ wèi zìjǐ, yào wèi dàjiā zhuóxiǎng.
examples.en: Don’t think only for yourself; think for everyone.

meaning: To ask; to inquire; to question someone about something; to make an inquiry or request information.
components: 问 is ⿵门口: 门 (mén) means “door” or “gate,” and 口 (kǒu) means “mouth.” A mouth at the door suggests someone standing at a doorway, opening their mouth to ask a question or make an inquiry.

examples.zh: 我可以问你一个问题吗？
examples.pinyin: Wǒ kěyǐ wèn nǐ yí gè wèntí ma?
examples.en: Can I ask you a question?

examples.zh: 他常常问老师很多问题。
examples.pinyin: Tā chángcháng wèn lǎoshī hěn duō wèntí.
examples.en: He often asks the teacher many questions.

examples.zh: 如果你不懂，就去问。
examples.pinyin: Rúguǒ nǐ bù dǒng, jiù qù wèn.
examples.en: If you don’t understand, then go and ask.

meaning: “问题” means a question, problem, or issue. It can refer to something you ask (a question), something that is wrong or not working (a problem), or a topic or matter that needs to be considered or solved.
components: 问: 门 (door) + 口 (mouth). A mouth at the door, asking or inquiring. 题: 是 (to be) + 页 (page/head). Originally linked to headings or titles on a page. Together, 问题 is something you ask about or a problem/topic raised for discussion.

examples.zh: 你有什么问题可以直接问我。
examples.pinyin: Nǐ yǒu shénme wèntí kěyǐ zhíjiē wèn wǒ.
examples.en: If you have any questions, you can ask me directly.

examples.pinyin: Zhè ge diànnǎo yǒu diǎn wèntí, zǒngshì zìjǐ guānjī.
examples.en: This computer has a bit of a problem; it keeps shutting down by itself.

examples.zh: 环境污染已经成了全球性的问题。
examples.pinyin: Huánjìng wūrǎn yǐjīng chéng le quánqiúxìng de wèntí.
examples.en: Environmental pollution has already become a global problem.

memoryStory: You knock on a giant glowing 门 door, but it only opens a tiny 口 mouth that shouts a quiz 题 at you: “WHAT is the problem?” To pass, you must answer every 问题 the door-mouth spits out, like rapid-fire test questions on floating pages.

meaning: Watermelon: a large, round or oval fruit with a hard green rind and sweet, juicy, usually red flesh. In Chinese it is a common everyday word for the fruit itself and can be used with measure words like 个 or 颗.
components:
西瓜 = 西 + 瓜.
- 西 (xī): Originally related to “west.” In modern form it looks like a roof or a lid over something. Here it mainly contributes the sound xī.
- 瓜 (guā): Means “melon” or “gourd.” The character looks like a hanging melon with vines or tendrils at the bottom. Together, 西瓜 literally means “western melon,” i.e., the melon that came from the west → watermelon.

examples.zh: 夏天吃冰镇西瓜特别解暑。
examples.pinyin: Xiàtiān chī bīngzhèn xīguā tèbié jiěshǔ.
examples.en: Eating chilled watermelon in summer is especially refreshing against the heat.

examples.zh: 他买了一个很大的西瓜，打算和朋友一起分着吃。
examples.pinyin: Tā mǎi le yí gè hěn dà de xīguā, dǎsuàn hé péngyou yìqǐ fēn zhe chī.
examples.en: He bought a very big watermelon and plans to share it with his friends.

examples.zh: 这块西瓜太甜了，我还想再来一片。
examples.pinyin: Zhè kuài xīguā tài tián le, wǒ hái xiǎng zài lái yí piàn.
examples.en: This piece of watermelon is so sweet, I want another slice.

memoryStory: Imagine the SUN setting in the WEST (西), and as it touches the horizon, it turns into a giant MELON (瓜). People cheer and slice the glowing western melon—西瓜—into juicy red cubes that spray you with sweet juice as you say “xī guā!”

rawDictEntry: 西瓜 西瓜 [xī guā] /watermelon/CL:顆|颗[kē],個|个[ge]/

meaning: 希望 means to hope, to wish, or a hope/wish itself. It expresses wanting something good to happen in the future, either as a verb (“to hope for…”) or as a noun (“there is still hope”).
components:
希: ⿱㐅布 — The top part 㐅 looks like something small or scattered; below is 布 (cloth). Imagine someone spreading out cloth, searching for a tiny chance. This gives the feeling of a delicate, faint hope. 
望: ⿱⿰亡月王 — On top is 亡 (to lose, to be gone), suggesting something missing or far away. Below, 月 (moon) and 王 (king). Picture a king looking at the distant moon for something that’s gone, gazing into the distance with longing. Together, 希望 is a delicate, searching gaze toward something far but desired: “hope.”

examples.zh: 我希望你每天都很开心。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ xīwàng nǐ měitiān dōu hěn kāixīn.
examples.en: I hope you are happy every day.

examples.zh: 只要不放弃，就还有希望。
examples.pinyin: Zhǐyào bù fàngqì, jiù hái yǒu xīwàng.
examples.en: As long as you don’t give up, there is still hope.

examples.zh: 这个计划给了我们新的希望。
examples.pinyin: Zhège jìhuà gěi le wǒmen xīn de xīwàng.
examples.en: This plan has given us new hope.

memoryStory: A shy king (王) loses (亡) his favorite moon-shaped (月) pillow and sadly stares at the moon every night, HOPING it will fall back down. His servants spread out cloth (布) everywhere, carefully searching for a tiny clue (㐅). Their whole kingdom lives on this one silly, shining “xīwàng.”

rawDictEntry: 希望 希望 [xī wàng] /to hope/a hope; a wish (CL:個|个[gè])/

meaning: 洗 (xǐ): to wash, to bathe, to clean; to develop photographs; to shuffle cards; to erase or wipe a recording. Less common reading 洗 (xiǎn) appears in the word 洗马, a historical title (literally “horse-washer”).
components: 洗 is ⿰氵先. 氵 is the ‘water’ radical, often related to liquids, cleaning, or actions with water. 先 means ‘first, earlier, ahead’. Put together: using water (氵) first (先) to wash and clean something before anything else.

examples.zh: 吃饭前一定要洗手。
examples.pinyin: Chī fàn qián yídìng yào xǐ shǒu.
examples.en: You must wash your hands before eating.

examples.zh: 这张照片洗得不好，我们重洗一遍吧。
examples.pinyin: Zhè zhāng zhàopiàn xǐ de bù hǎo, wǒmen chóng xǐ yí biàn ba.
examples.en: This photo wasn’t developed well; let’s develop it again.

examples.zh: 昨天玩牌的时候，他一直在洗牌。
examples.pinyin: Zuótiān wán pái de shíhou, tā yìzhí zài xǐpái.
examples.en: When we played cards yesterday, he kept shuffling the deck.

memoryStory: A commander named Xǐ (third tone dip) shouts: “First! (先) Use water (氵)!” Before battle, he makes soldiers wash everything—armor, horses, even playing cards—so clean that their battle recordings are ‘washed away’. Whenever you hear xǐ, imagine his obsessive washing ritual.
imagePrompt: In a sleek sci‑fi bathroom, a robot with glowing circuits washes its metallic hands under a floating stream of blue holographic water, while hologram photos and playing cards around it are being rinsed clean, data lines and neon networks running along the walls.
rawDictEntry: 洗 洗 [xǐ] /to wash; to bathe/to develop (photographs)/to shuffle (cards etc)/to erase (a recording)/

meaning: 向 (xiàng): toward, to face, to turn toward; direction; to be oriented to; to support or side with; shortly before; formerly; always/all along. Also a surname (Xiàng). Used widely for physical direction, tendencies, and orientation in space or attitude.
components:
向 is written as ⿵⿱丿冂口.
- 丿 (piě): a slanting stroke, like something leaning or turning.
- 冂 (jiōng): an open frame or border, like a doorway or an open space.
- 口 (kǒu): mouth, an opening or a person speaking.
Together: a leaning stroke entering an open frame with a mouth inside — imagine someone turning their face and mouth toward an opening or direction. This matches the idea of “facing” or “toward.”

examples.zh: 请向右转，然后一直走。
examples.pinyin: Qǐng xiàng yòu zhuǎn, ránhòu yīzhí zǒu.
examples.en: Please turn to the right, then keep walking straight.

examples.zh: 他一直向我表示支持。
examples.pinyin: Tā yīzhí xiàng wǒ biǎoshì zhīchí.
examples.en: He has always shown support toward me.

examples.zh: 窗户向南，阳光很好。
examples.pinyin: Chuānghu xiàng nán, yángguāng hěn hǎo.
examples.en: The window faces south, and the sunlight is great.

memoryStory: Picture a big open door (冂) with a talking mouth (口) stuck in the middle, loudly giving directions. A slanted arrow (丿) leans toward the door, as if your whole body is turning that way. The noisy mouth shouts “Face THIS WAY!”—you turn TOWARD it: xiàng.
imagePrompt: A futuristic hallway with glowing arrows on the floor all pointing toward a bright doorway. In the doorway floats a holographic mouth giving directions. Neon lines form a network on the walls, all converging toward that doorway, emphasizing direction and facing toward it.

meaning: An hour; a unit of time equal to sixty minutes, used to talk about how long something takes or how long it lasts.
components: 小 (xiǎo) means “small” or “little.” 时 (shí) is composed of 日 (sun, day, time) on the left and 寸 (cùn, a small length, hand/measurement) on the right. Together, 小 + 时 suggests a “small piece of time” — an hour.

examples.zh: 我等了你一个小时。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ děng le nǐ yí gè xiǎoshí.
examples.en: I waited for you for an hour.

examples.zh: 从这里到机场要半个小时。
examples.pinyin: Cóng zhèlǐ dào jīchǎng yào bàn gè xiǎoshí.
examples.en: It takes half an hour to get from here to the airport.

examples.zh: 他每天学习中文三个小时。
examples.pinyin: Tā měitiān xuéxí Zhōngwén sān gè xiǎoshí.
examples.en: He studies Chinese for three hours every day.

meaning: To laugh; to smile; to express amusement or happiness with one’s face or voice; can also mean to laugh at or mock someone depending on context.
components: 笑 is ⿱竹夭. Top: 竹 (zhú) ‘bamboo’, also the bamboo radical often seen in characters related to bamboo or things made from it. Bottom: 夭 (yāo) meaning ‘bent, tender, young, lively’. Put together, it evokes a lively, bending (curving) expression under bamboo—like someone’s face curving into a smile while hiding in bamboo.

examples.zh: 听到那个笑话，他突然大笑起来。
examples.pinyin: Tīngdào nàge xiàohuà, tā tūrán dàxiào qǐlái.

examples.pinyin: Tā de xiào hěn wēnnuǎn, ràng rén juéde hěn fàngsōng.

examples.pinyin: Bié xiào tā, tā yǐjīng hěn nánguò le.
examples.en: Don’t laugh at him; he’s already very upset.

meaning: “新” means new, fresh, recent, or newly. It can describe new objects (a new book), new situations or changes (a new job, new policy), and recent actions (newly arrived, just married). It can also appear in names like Xinjiang (新疆) or Singapore (新加坡).
components: “新” is ⿰亲斤, made of 亲 and 斤. 亲 originally shows a parent bending toward a child, meaning “close, dear.” 斤 is an axe, a tool for chopping. Put together, imagine using an axe to cut away the old so your dear family can enjoy something new and fresh—this gives the idea of “new.”

examples.zh: 我买了一件新衣服。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ mǎile yí jiàn xīn yīfu.
examples.en: I bought a new piece of clothing.

examples.zh: 欢迎新同学！

examples.zh: 他刚找到一份新工作。
examples.pinyin: Tā gāng zhǎodào yí fèn xīn gōngzuò.
examples.en: He just found a new job.

meaning: Family name; surname; to have a certain family name. Used when talking about one’s last name, as in introducing oneself or asking someone’s surname.
components: 姓 is ⿰女生: 女 (nǚ, woman/female) on the left + 生 (shēng, to be born) on the right. Traditionally, a child is ‘born from a woman’, and the family line (and thus the family name) continues through birth. Together, they suggest ‘the name you are born with’ → surname.

examples.en: What is your family name?

examples.zh: 我姓王，叫王明。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ xìng Wáng, jiào Wáng Míng.
examples.en: My family name is Wang; I’m called Wang Ming.

examples.zh: 她姓李，不姓张。
examples.pinyin: Tā xìng Lǐ, bù xìng Zhāng.
examples.en: Her surname is Li, not Zhang.

meaning: To rest, take a break, or relax after activity or work; to pause in order to recover energy, health, or focus.
components: 休: ⿰亻(木) — left side 亻 is the “person” radical, right side 木 is “tree.” Picture a person leaning against a tree to rest. 息: ⿱自(心) — top 自 originally a nose/oneself, bottom 心 is “heart.” Together it suggests one’s own breath and heart calming down, like breathing and relaxing. 休息 combines “person resting by a tree” + “breath/heart calming” to mean resting and taking a break.

examples.en: You’re too tired, take a short rest first.

meaning: 雪 (xuě) most commonly means “snow,” the frozen white precipitation that falls from the sky (measure word: 场 cháng). In literary or formal usage, it can also mean “to wipe out, to wash away (a humiliation, injustice, or shame).” As a surname, it is pronounced Xue.
components: 雪 is written ⿱雨彐. Top: 雨 (yǔ), meaning “rain” or things falling from the sky. Bottom: 彐 (jì), originally a snout/curved shape, here acting as a phonetic component. Together, “rain from above” plus a phonetic hint gives the idea of special ‘rain’—frozen rain: snow.

examples.pinyin: Tā xiǎng tōngguò nǔlì lái xuě qiánchǐ.
examples.en: He wants to wipe away his former humiliation through hard work.

meaning: 颜色 means color in general (such as red, blue, etc.), and by extension appearance or look. It can also refer to facial expression (often emotional), or to pigment/dyestuff used for painting, printing, or dyeing.
components: “颜” is ⿰彦页. 彦 originally suggests a talented or elegant person; 页 is a head, so 颜 relates to the face or facial area. “色” is ⿱𠂊巴. 𠂊 shows a person’s upper body, and 巴 suggests curling or clinging; together 色 originally depicted physical appearance or sensual attraction. Combined, 颜色 literally links the face (颜) and appearance (色) → the colors and look that appear to our eyes.

examples.zh: 你最喜欢什么颜色？
examples.pinyin: Nǐ zuì xǐhuan shénme yánsè?
examples.en: What is your favorite color?

examples.pinyin: Tiānkōng de yánsè cóng lánsè mànman biànchéng chéngsè.
examples.en: The color of the sky slowly changes from blue to orange.

examples.zh: 听到这个消息，他脸上的颜色一下子变了。
examples.pinyin: Tīngdào zhège xiāoxi, tā liǎn shàng de yánsè yíxiàzi biàn le.
examples.en: After hearing the news, the color/expression on his face suddenly changed.

A tiny robot person 𠂊 hugs a glowing 巴 tail that keeps changing into neon red, blue, and green. Every time the tail changes color, the big face’s expression and skin 颜色 flash to match—so you remember 颜 (face) + 色 (appearance) = 颜色, color and facial expression.

meaning: Eyes; the pair of organs used for seeing, located on the face. Can refer to one eye or both eyes depending on context and measure word.
components: 眼: ⿰目艮 — Left is 目 (eye, vision), a common radical for things related to seeing. Right is 艮, which can suggest stopping or stubbornness; here it helps form the sound and hints at a fixed, steady gaze. 睛: ⿰目青 — Left is 目 (eye) again. Right is 青 (green/blue, youthful, bright), suggesting clarity, brightness, and vivid color. Together, 眼睛 emphasizes clear, bright eyes used for seeing the world.

examples.zh: 她的眼睛很大，很漂亮。
examples.pinyin: Tā de yǎn jing hěn dà, hěn piàoliang.
examples.en: Her eyes are very big and very beautiful.

examples.zh: 看书太久要让眼睛休息一下。

meaning: Mutton; goat or sheep meat used as food. In everyday Chinese, 羊肉 usually refers to meat from sheep or goats, especially in dishes like skewers, hotpot, and stews.
components: 羊: Looks like a horned animal with decorations on its head; it represents a sheep or goat. The breakdown ⿱䒑⿻二丨 hints at the horns and head shape. 肉: A pictograph of a piece of meat or flesh, representing meat or the body. Together, 羊 (sheep/goat) + 肉 (meat) = sheep/goat meat (mutton).

examples.zh: 我最喜欢吃羊肉串。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ zuì xǐhuan chī yángròu chuàn.

meaning: Medicine; drug; remedy; a substance used for treating illness or for a specific effect (such as poisoning, explosions, fermenting). Also used more generally for any ‘chemical’ or active agent.
components: 药 = ⿱艹 + 约. 艹 is the “grass/plant” radical, often related to herbs, plants, and medicines. 约 (yuē, to bind/contract) suggests something controlled or measured. Together: a plant-based substance that is carefully measured and controlled → medicine, drug.

examples.zh: 医生让我每天吃三次药。

meaning: 要 has two main readings. yào: to want; to need; to ask for; will; shall; to be about to; need to; should; if (as in 要是). yāo (bound form): to demand; to coerce. It often expresses desire, necessity, or future intention.
components: 要 is written as ⿱覀女. The top part 覀 (yà) is a variant of 西, often associated with the west or a cover/roof-like shape. The bottom 女 means “woman.” Historically, the character’s structure is more phonetic than logical, but you can imagine a woman (女) under a cover/top (覀) insisting on or needing something, which fits the ideas of “want,” “need,” and “demand.”

examples.zh: 我要喝水。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ yào hē shuǐ.
examples.en: I want to drink water.

examples.zh: 明天要下雨了。
examples.pinyin: Míngtiān yào xià yǔ le.
examples.en: It’s going to rain tomorrow.

examples.en: If you want to go, I’ll go with you.

meaning: 也 (yě) is a common adverb meaning “also, too, as well.” It can add another item, action, or person to what was just mentioned (e.g., “I also…,” “she too…”). In literary Chinese it can act as a final particle, somewhat like a softer, explanatory “ah.”
components: 也 is a single-component character with no separate radical inside. Historically, its shape is related to a bent figure or a twist, and over time it came to be used as a grammatical word meaning “also, too.” Since there’s no obvious picture clue, it’s usually memorized as a standalone shape and sound: 也 (yě).

examples.zh: 我也想去。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ yě xiǎng qù.
examples.en: I also want to go.

examples.zh: 他很累，我也很累。
examples.pinyin: Tā hěn lèi, wǒ yě hěn lèi.
examples.en: He is very tired; I’m also very tired.

examples.zh: 今天不冷，也不热。
examples.pinyin: Jīntiān bù lěng, yě bù rè.
examples.en: Today it’s neither cold nor hot, either.

Me ALSO want oil!” The funny bent pose is 也, always jumping in to say “also, too.” The rising third tone yě sounds like the robot’s eager “yeh? me too!”

meaning: 已经 means “already,” indicating that an action or situation has happened or is completed, often earlier than expected or relative to another time. It’s commonly paired with 了 or 过 but can also stand alone to emphasize that something is no longer in a previous state.
components:
已: A simple character that originally shows a curved shape, often explained as a form of ‘already finished, stopped, or turned’. It carries the idea of something that has come to an end.
经: Left side 纟 is the “silk” radical, related to threads, lines, or continuity. Right side 𢀖 (jīng) acts as the sound component and also suggests a path or warp threads in weaving. 经 can mean ‘to pass through, to undergo, warp threads, classic text’. Together, 已经 combines ‘already’ (已) + ‘to pass through / undergo’ (经) → something has already been gone through or has already taken place.

examples.zh: 我已经吃过早饭了。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ yǐjīng chī guò zǎofàn le.
examples.en: I’ve already eaten breakfast.

examples.zh: 天已经黑了，我们回家吧。
examples.pinyin: Tiān yǐjīng hēi le, wǒmen huí jiā ba.
examples.en: It’s already dark; let’s go home.

examples.zh: 他已经工作十年了。
examples.pinyin: Tā yǐjīng gōngzuò shí nián le.
examples.en: He has already worked for ten years.

memoryStory: Imagine a silk factory in the future. The boss shouts: “已经!” (“already!”). The ‘已’ robot arm has already stopped moving, because the job is finished. The ‘纟’ silk threads and ‘经’ warp lines on a glowing loom show cloth that has already been woven and passed through the machine.

meaning: Together; in the same place or at the same time; in company with; altogether, in total; also used for one occurrence or case of an event (e.g., an accident, a dispute).
components:
一: means “one,” suggesting unity or a single group.
起: component ⿺走 shows the “walk/move” radical 走, and 巳 hints at sound. Together, 起 means “to rise, to start.”
Putting them together, 一起 literally feels like “as one, start/move,” i.e. people acting or moving as one — together.

meaning: 1) Meaning; sense; idea of something. 2) Intention, wish, or opinion. 3) Interest, fun (“有意思” = interesting). 4) A token of appreciation or goodwill (often modestly: “一点小意思”).
components: 意: ⿱音心 – The top 音 means “sound,” the bottom 心 is “heart.” Together, 意 suggests the “sound of the heart” → thoughts, ideas, intentions. 思: ⿱田心 – The top 田 is “field,” the bottom 心 is “heart.” A heart thinking about a field → pondering, thinking. 意思 combines “heart-sound” and “heart-thinking” → the idea, meaning, or intention that comes from what your heart is thinking and expressing.

examples.en: This movie is very interesting.

examples.pinyin: Zhè shì yīdiǎn xiǎo yìsi, qǐng shōu xià.
examples.en: This is just a small token of appreciation, please accept it.
